taW3vU5j5BxmVFhhTtXsfw.review_text: When I'm in the mood for large portions of above average American diner food, I think of Max's. I love the Patti Melt here, but I've enjoyed all the dishes I've tried at Max's over the years.  And Max's has my favorite desert, a chocolate macaroon crumble, which is basically vanilla ice cream, covered with a coconut macaroon that's been covered in dark chocolate sauce, and tons of it. I've tried the other deserts, and they've all been good, but this one remains my favorite.  Portions are so large here that I can't imagine eating both dinner and desert in one sitting, so I usually go for either one or the other, otherwise it's a waste of food.  I've eaten at the Max's Opera Cafe in SF, Max's Cafe in Redwood City, Max's Cafe in Palo Alto and Max's Restaurant and Bar in Burlingame, and they've all been pretty much the same.

jIZqQ6JUHDH0GJHW9RM0jA.review_text: I have eaten here several times over the past five years, mainly before attending events at the San Francisco Opera House.  After my experience last night I've had enough of this place.  The food is decent but nothing memorable.  I accept this, however,  as Max's mainly is a deli that serves dinner.  If one wants a better culinary experience there are plenty of good restaurants in the area.  My big issue is the service.  For example, last night we arrived at 6:00 and were seated about five minutes later.  We did not see our waiter until about 6:25.  We told him that we had 7:30 opera tickets, to which he replied "I can't guarantee anything" regarding when we would get our food.  We ordered our drinks and food at the same time.  Fifteen minutes later our food came out, but our drinks were nowhere to be seen.  After prompting the bus person to find our waiter, he delivered our drinks a few minutes later.  Our waiter didn't display any sign of urgency despite the busy night.  It appeared that he just didn't care.  My one star for Max's is not for our single experience last night.  Max's has earned this star based upon poor and indifferent service on most of my visits.  I'd rather eat at the McDonald's across the street than return to Max's.   I'll at least be treated better by the kids behind the counter.

BsRhkiDWVVdRbaJcbbb47g.review_text: Max's is one of those places that for some reason it never occurs to me to visit.   But the last time I visited, I had such a great experience.  It was a rainy, cold Sunday night.  And it was the birthday of a loved one who has since passed away, so we were all feeling a bit melancholic.  And nostalgic.  And hungry.  And driving down Gough.  When someone suggested Max's.    So glad we went -- we were greeted warmly, and seated at a table near the grand piano.  The pianist was playing a wonderful medley of Broadway show tunes -- coincidentally some of our departed loved one's favorites.  Then, one of the waiters stood at the mic and sang.  It was so beautiful.  At a nearby table, a birthday was being celebrated, and a trio of waiters sang "Happy Birthday" in perfect harmony. Such synchronicity is a joy.   The bread was great, a nice selection of sourdough rolls, walnut-cranberry rolls and whole wheat slices.  And our waiter very graciously kept refilling the basket.  Entrees were fine -- but what was really memorable were the desserts -- so yummy, and such giant portions -- we ordered the Opera Cake, the hot fudge sundae, and the apple crisp.  Wow!  So fabulous!  We ended up taking half of every portion home!     Parking in this area can be a real pain in the ass, but there is a garage underneath if you can't find street parking.

ZXNwO2bY3QTYP0k_5bhG1A.review_text: After enjoying a morning concert at the Herbst theater nearby, we were in need of brunch. The yelp app showed the family-friendly places in the theater district were few and far between. Max's was really the only obvious choice, being a mere block away. We made a beeline.  On entering, we discovered we were not alone. The foyer was filled to the brim with waiting families, some on their way to The Nutcracker performance nearby. I sheepishly asked the wait time at the host desk and they said "15 minutes."  Though I was extremely doubtful, I gave them my name, got a pager and sat with the family.  To their word, 15 minutes later we had a nice window table with menus in hand. I was amazed.  My hungry family ordered quickly.  I also opted for coffee and bloody mary (Hey, they were half price!). The coffee was good, and the bloody mary was spot-on; They even rimmed the glass with celery salt. Yum.  My huevos rancheros plate was much much better than I expected. It included perfectly-cooked eggs, good beans, guacamole, and home fries. Plus, triple-sized, delicious, homemade tortilla chips were tucked in around the sides. And it wasn't overburdened with cheese, like most places.  I then polled the family on their opinion:   The oldest daughter: "I love this place!"   The wife: "mreeymgudmm" (in the middle of enjoying her salad)   The youngest daughter: "Can we come back here?"  In the end the news was both good and bad.  The good - we have a decent, family place to eat for the next theater trip.  The bad - my kids will now expect to always come here whenever we're in the neighborhood.

GU66uZwx4y2-0-i5ddr8FA.review_text: I can only give this place one half of a star for the only time I have had a wholly satisfying meal here. It was take-out, for lunch, and only a half a wrap, so there for a half star is only appropriate.  If it had been a whole wrap, perhaps a whole star... Anyway, it doesn't matter.  After several attempts over the last four years of working at City Hall and having desperate deli cravings absolutely dashed to pieces upon one crappy Max experience after another, I have sworn off for good.   Recap of my last experience:   (Scene) It is raining absolutely sideways, we run from City Hall to the safety of Opera Plaza.  Throw open the doors to Max's and slosh through the nearly empty restaurant to the hostess stand.  Hostess: Yeah?  Us: Um, yeah.  We would like to get lunch.  Hostess: Well...you can sit at the bar.  We walk in the direction of her thumb, which she has just casually thrown over her shoulder, and sit down at the bar.   Mind you, Max's has just renovated from one horrific interior to something equally horrific, which is good because we have something to talk about as we wait for interminably long periods of time between any waitstaff attention throughout our meal. Honestly, it looks like a monster with a penchant for green and pink Smooth & Melty's lost his lunch inside a slick chinese restaurant.  I do like the chandeliers, though. On to the rest of our lunch....  The waiter brings us menus, does not ask if we would like drinks, and leaves.  Another waiter comes, gives us water, leaves.  A third waitress comes. We order.   10 minutes later, we get our appetizer "Baked Giant Mushrooms with Pecorino Cheese and Pesto".  Now, wouldn't you think that they would be warm? Yes? Well, you would be wrong. Wouldn't you think the mushrooms would at least be large, if not giant? Wrong again.  We got 4 cold, not-so-big mushrooms in a tepid (at best) marinara sauce.  Generally, my lunch partner and I are not complainers--we are too afraid of spit.  In this case, however, we had to say something.  At two dollars a pop, we were not going to eat lukewarm mushrooms.  So we did.  The waitress STUCK HER THUMB in one of the mushrooms and said, "yep, you're right" and whisked them away.  She returned 10 MINUTES later with our plate maybe two degrees warmer than the last time, and made a huge deal about the fact that she gave us an extra, "free" mushroom, on her....Well thanks a ton, lady.   Our lunch continues in this downhill trajectory...my buddy's Rueben comes with no 1000 dressing, and he has to ask for ketchup for his french-fries too (I know, bizarre request, but still...) The cheese on his sandwich is, yes, melted, which would imply that it was once warm, but in fact it too is chilly to the touch.  So okay, maybe warm food is not their thing? On to my salad...which I never found under the huge glob of sour cream that they put on top of it.   Oh, and the desserts, which used to be the restaurants only saving grace, have been downsized. This is not my imagination, we asked and it was confirmed. And don't even get me started about the time I got a half a salad for the bargain price of $17 dollars....

ioM4gJI5WmmahP6xp0sTmA.review_text: We used to be fans of Max's.  Yes, the portions were too large and the prices matched the portions, but you got good deli food -- pastrami, sliders, etc., just nothing for those of us who want lighter food.   When we went today,  I was cheered.  There was a page of salads, vegetarian wraps and seafood.  I settled for a crab cake appetizer and another of our party ordered the red snapper.  The other two ordered a burger and a chicken pot pie.  The burger and pot pie were the way we remembered Max's -- huge portions and lots of calories.  The crab cakes were relatively small with more bread and less crab than I've had in years.  The coleslaw that came with them was brightly colored slivers of cabbage, with not much else, including taste.  The snapper was heavily breaded and fried, the the sauce did not complement the fish.  Only our ravenous burger son felt satisfied.   I've always preferred other restaurants in San Francisco; now the rest of the family agrees with me.

KHbe_wTBW4KHcjDIs3mHMw.review_text: *Cue Fiddler on the Roof music* Traditioooooon!  That's what I think of when I hear Max's.  My family and I go here after every opera, every symphony, and every ballet (or before if it's too late).  Their menu is created in the finest traditions of Jewish delicatessens the world over, but with plenty of other cuisines and choices so as to keep everyone happy.  I can't think of anything better than a bowl of their to-die-for matzoh ball soup and a reuben, along with a Dr. Brown's cream soda or cel-ray tonic.  The Van Ness location still features singing employees on certain nights, which is always entertaining.  I love this place, and you will too.

c_X8F5M5MxR0fFFWAShooQ.review_text: We have a yearly tradition of taking our kids to Max's prior to the Nutcracker ballet. It is something we look forward to, as I am sure the restaurant is well aware of the Nutcracker customers that follow this same tradition.  We recently dined at Max's on 12/14/11. We arrived at 5:00p, and were the first table in an empty section. While waiting for over 20 minutes for a server to take a drink order, we noticed the section getting fuller and fuller. When our server, Blanca, finally decided to come to our table, we could tell that she was in a foul mood.   We finally got served our dinner after a full hour of waiting. The restaurant was in full swing by then with a line forming on the waiting list. One would think, if you are the manager of a restaurant with guaranteed customers going to the Nutcracker, that you would schedule your best and most efficient servers to make the most money, right?  Blanca forgot most of our order. She left ALL of the dirty plates and cups on the table for the ENTIRE meal. I had to hunt her down to order a glass of wine with my dinner, and again to order dessert for my kids. Whenever you tried to get her attention, she blatantly ignored us - as well as most of the table in her section.  While I usually am not one to post comments on Yelp, this disaster of a dining experience was just too much to ignore. The final straw was when she gave us our bill with a built in 18% gratuity. Seriously? So you flat out ignore your customers, forget most of their order, never clear the table or ask if we need anything, and then slap our faces with 18% for doing NOTHING? A complete insult in my opinion!  Sadly, I think our dining tradition prior to attending the ballet will be finding a new location. It's too bad that the management has become so uninterested in customer experience. In these tough economic times, customer service is EVERYTHING and should NEVER be taken for granted.

In the last few years, I've been disappointed by each experience. The Niagara Falls cake which was my reason for living, just isn't the same. The meal I had on Max's on the Square was flavorless. And yesterday I went to the one on Van Ness to get a 7 layer bar. I saw them in the display case and they were huge! I greedily thought I'd be getting more of something I've always loved. But no, it's dry, hardly any flavor, and so big I couldn't get it in my mouth. Way too many butterscotch chips and not enough coconut milk and chocolate chips. I was so disappointed. pMltyeuU4SjT6Y8YVy7HBA.review_text: A popular spot to go to prior to seeing the opera or the symphony, Max is traditional pretentious romantic San Franciscan charm at its finest and it will win over your heart to a certain extent.  With a pianist playing jazzy versions of Billy Joel's "Don't Go Changin (to try and please me....)" you are served by the waiters and waitresses who actually perform and sing.  That's an interesting perk.  But as you all know, singers are often primadonnas which means that there is a risk of emotionally unstable service.  Although I can report that this wasn't the case, the service was very slow even after we warned them we had an 8pm opera to see.  Could our server have been more concerned about hitting a certain note for a song than the status of our order?  The food was not bad.  The prime rib was excellent, and the desserts are gigantic.  One order is enough for three people.  The seating for the most part is too tight unless you get lucky and get a booth, which there are a few.  The menu selection is extensive.  Be warned that most servings are large enough for two people.   Also be warned not to commit to a favorite dish.  I loved a certain lasagna dish and it is no longer on the menu.  If you have a show at 8pm, do not go to Max's Opera Cafe unless you can get there at 6pm.  Otherwise, you will not be able to enjoy its relaxing, slick ambience.

W-sq3lr18TNcfAwKjzU5Jw.review_text: The last time I was there, I didn't care for it. I gave it another chance now that I work in S.F. again, YUM! I only ordered the burger at lunch time and the loved the huge steak fries.   Will be coming back again.

Ps7p9g4yfcOvqvla_tA89g.review_text: We stopped in for a quick meal before the opera.  I went the non-deli way with a meal of roast chicken, roast zucchini and lentils.  The food was okay.  For a real treat try Max's deli fare.  It's one of the few places in the Bay Area to get anything approaching deli food.  In that department I would rate it 4 stars.

ipleTHGh9KR8hO5U1yxzXw.review_text: Yes I was sick and no I couldn't even swallow (food people!!!....nasty).  Nonetheless I went to Max's Opera Cafe to kill one hour of my time and ordered the yummiest concoction that I have had the pleasure of having for dessert. 83oMT1KMDTrJE2XXftS1qg.review_text: I had pretty good service and the pastrami sandwich was really good.  There's always an interesting crowd when I go here- great place to bring my 80 year old dad- he fits right in

yA7t1I5Z7-GcJX7NgkgwoA.review_text: Max's for at least two decades has been a great, consistent full service joint that has wonderful enticements in addition to the copious size of there portions.  I've gone there so many times and at some many of their once vast group of locations and always come back to The Opera Plaza original.  We've been going recently every Friday night and unfortunately we stopped after most of noticed little changes and short cuts creeping into the menu and service.  Our last visit was our final visit, at least for the time being, because one in our regular group who normally orders their recently shrinking burger, decided to order the Old Fashion Turkey dinner which sounds great on the menu and was a startling, beyond repair disaster that night.  It came after the rest of us had our entree's and when it came we all shuddered as we looked at the platter.  There were the potatos, carrots, cranberry sauce, but the turkey itself was Kirkwood Luncheon slide turkey rolled up to make it look a little better than it is.  Everything on his plate cold and he asked the waiter what happened to fresh cooked REAL turkey and the waiter was at a loss and seemed embarrassed about the $18.95 presentation.  He wanted nothing to replace his dinner and each of the rest of us experience sympathy pains and felt like we were being ripped off by Max's for the first time in all those years.  My burger and the patty melt the week before have shrunk, the portions of everything seems to have grown smaller almost overnight, and the staff seems new to boot.  I have no idea what is going on there, but it's sad and I'm sorry to not have Max's as part of our regular dining, especially because we all love the piano bar man, Larry O'Leno, he's stellar.

0SlTRHS6akfOJe7E0iybPw.review_text: My boyfriend and I went on a rainy Monday night. He suggested I order the chinese chicken salad. It was good for the most part. I think the chicken was a bit dry and overly fried and there was too much ciilantro piled up on top of the salad. I guess cilantro is a cheap way of making a salad portion look bigger! FIwu9HNDhgkj1WW8K-JAiQ.review_text: The Ceasar Sald that we ordered to go was large and reasonably good, but the service was horrible.  the young lad who took my order was barely able to speak english and after waiting a very long time, he got the order wrong.  on top of that, the restaurant charges a 5.4% employment  benefit fee on top on the regular tax and gratuity.  many San Francisco restaurants are doing this and in the future, I refuse to pay this fee and will avoid all restaurants that expect their customers to pay for employee benefits.

5jq_1AngK0Q4eJqk-dS0Kg.review_text: I have been to the Max's in Corte Madera more times than I can count, and this place is just like it. I ordered the hot pastrami sandwich, as always. pS5pn0WkA86z88oZh1HSPw.review_text: This place is popular probably for specific dishes on the menu.  It used to be a great destination for late night dining and large groups craving deli food when there were fewer options.  For the most part, the food is mediocre but you can share a huge, monster sandwich with a gigantic side of slaw or fries.  The takeout line is slow during the week.  I agree with Molly B. that the place and menu are strange.

ss1PGLjfjitXP2o0_95SCA.review_text: Huge!!  That is all I can really say. HUGE!  Not really my thing but I'm not going to say it's bad either.

DMwp6ZDmshHRPeQVrYGoqQ.review_text: So, I had a sick child at home this week. OK, so he's 38, but really, aren't we all children who want to be taken care of when we have the flu?  I thought that some matzo-ball soup was in order and this was the closest place to my office to get some on my way home. I remembered having their latkes at a holiday party that were delish, so I got some of those, too. Then I figured that with the soup I should get a sandwich to share. Here's where a problem lay. My standard for Jewish deli food is the fabulous, amazing "Famous 4th Street Deli" in Philly, where the sandwiches are big enough to feed a family of 6 and the matzo-ball soup, which is the best I've ever had, could feed Somalia. So at Max's, I was expecting huge portions of yummy food.   The large soup was just enough for the 2 of us, but it wasn't spectacular. I was happy that it wasn't too salty, a problem that many soups have, and that the chicken was white meat. It was OK, but it didn't leave me anticipating my next visit. Same with the roast beef sandwich. It was a decent sandwich; nothing to complain about. But nothing to really remember, either. The latkes, however, were just as tasty as I remembered them.   So, next time I have a sick child at home, I'll try one of the Russian places on Geary that always seem to have a good supply of fresh matzo-ball soup.

Jk3-Z6Kjb0wUUnXxOI2iNw.review_text: Sunday Brunch in a corner street Dinner. Very amazing desserts! and the portions are large. Matzo ball soup and half pastrami sandwich is really good. Service is on auto pilot but I don't mind that as long as it gets done. You want to leave satisfied? With these plates it's guaranteed.

9cZhf2e7TVQ9S5PC9itvzw.review_text: Many Jews will tell you, "Oh, my (grand)mother makes THE best matzoh ball soup."  However, when I say it, I am telling the truth.   My mom's soup is extraordinary.  Her broth is sublime and her matzoh balls (or bumbahs as we call them) are nothing short of ethereal.  Often when she makes it, she'll exclaim "I've outdone myself!"  The funny thing is she doesn't even like matzoh ball soup.  And, she'll share her recipe with no one, only my sister.  She'll gladly tell you, however, that the number one ingredient in a matzoh ball is "love."  "You have to want to make a good matzoh ball otherwise you won't," she'd tell you.  This evening I was feeling a little under the weather.  Often when I do, I crave good ole Jewish chicken soup.  So, I dragged my goyish boyfriend here tonight so I could get my matzoh ball on.  Granted my standards are high but the bumbahs here were pretty bad.  They were kinda sweet as if they had added sugar.  Even the bf knew they were bad and he's from Iowa.  The broth & noodles were decent though.  All, however, was not lost.  I did get to indulge in a really good corned beef & pastrami sandwich.  The meat was moist and flavorful and not too fatty.  He got the pork chop which while a bit overdone came in really good, tangy sauce.  They had a piano player playing this evening which was a nice touch.  And, when she went on break the played Ella & Billie tunes which was cool.  So, all in all, this ain't my mom's house but it did in a pinch.

kKuJF6GFyZgp_E2rx8LNgQ.review_text: Went to Max's after a disappointing sushi dinner (documented here) to eat second dinner.  Yes, second dinner.  I managed to eat a whole burger here and the burger was good, but that was probably influenced by my hunger and disappointment in the sushi dinner we had already eaten.  The girlfriend ordered Mississippi Mud Pie (she went straight for dessert) and it looked delicious, enough so that she took some home.  An insider tip here is to request the bread.  They give bread at the table but only upon request.  The Girl has come here a number of times (I've only been here once) and she enjoys going despite having once found hair in her food, and her friend once being served undercooked chicken.  I guess that says something about the fries because that's what she raves about most here.

RH6hylsftJdIRWsC77xlug.review_text: There is probably a lot to say about Max's, not only the Opera Plaza location but its other locations, past and present.  The thing is that the menu is enormous, widely scaled, which they proudly brag about in their menu-ese-y declarations.  To put it simply, I've found a number of things on their menu that I enjoy  and find to be largely consistent in their presentation and quality.  The place gets mobbed at certain times and service can vary a bit.  There is a huge staff, none of whom I can recall seeing twice.  But, let me get to the point.  The thing that has been bringing me back time and time again lately is their kiwi lemon drop.  Made with a freshly-squeezed and mashed kiwi, it's both green and delightful.  I could drink 'em by the thermosful.  They do good cocktails as well as large-plated meals.  So, I gotta say, I like it.  And there is a Peet's Coffee right nearby to cleanse the pallate and encourage digestion and caffeine jitters.

9zHdo9pW4uT6pDo2ATme6g.review_text: I hadn't been to Max's in a few years so the reduced menu was disappointing, but that wouldn't have earned it this bad review. It was 5:30 before opera and symphony. The restaurant was busy but there were empty tables, and we were never warned by the hostess or wait staff that there could be a wait for food. I ordered a cobb salad, my companion ordered a lamb burger medium well. 30 minutes later we flagged the server down to check where our food was - only then did she update us. A few minutes later it arrived. The burger was brown on the outside and raw - I mean bacteria cold - on the inside. My salad - the greens were brown and wilted, as if they'd been dressed for at least an hour. Piled on top were dry chicken breast with no dressing to moisten it and a pile of brown and somewhat slimy mushrooms. Have you ever gotten up from a table in a restaurant to walk your own plate back to the kitchen because the wait staff can't be flagged? Incredible! The hostess offered to put our orders back in and comp us part of the bill, but we canceled the meal and walked out. That's my last visit to Max's.

NMFo89-qvGPf3_iuh30gFg.review_text: I can't tell you how many times I've eaten at Max's -- I've been to at least 5 different Max's over the years, but mostly I've dined at the Opera Plaza location.  I've always had great food and great service.  However, about 6 months ago, we received really bad service at Opera Plaza, sowe stopped going... I will still go to Max's -- just not this location.  Something is SERIOUSLY wrong with the way this location operates.  I miss the days when the servers were friendly, the service prompt and the orders were correct.  Thankfully, the last time I was at the Stanford location and the San Ramon location, everything was fine.  I think the fat lady is singing at the Opera Plaza location...

5osEI6bEhbaHr0n3FvZdMg.review_text: Max's is many things right now - a neighborhood bar (bartenders exceptional) with friendly banter among regulars, newcomers, locals and event patrons, a deli/burger/comfort food place - nothing fancy but consistently high quality, and a quirky one-of-a-kind joint with singing waiters and an all-are-welcome attitude.   I was going to write a review about how disappointed I was in the Keller Burger Bar the other day until I realized that the sweet potatoe fries were better at Max's than at the Burger Bar, so I opted to give Max's Opera Cafe a heads up instead.

vcEnNJqrL-jUtg_Z5e4D0Q.review_text: Yay for the new happy hour deals! You can only eat the happy hour food at the bar so be sure to get there early and secure your seat. The drinks are alright. They did the job. I ordered a peach margarita ($6) and it was pleasantly strong. We also ordered some food, all of which were $6. We got the angus sliders (2), portabello mushroom fries (loved this!), and potato skins (pretty average). My coworkers also got the clams (pretty good), the quesadilla (small-ish portion but comes with salsa/guac/sour cream), and the veggie & spinach dip platter (skimpy portions). The food is pretty decent and it's so close to work that I'd probably come back again for the happy hour. Otherwise it's just OK.

Rt2zPxW7yyPrj2ew6RyDUw.review_text: I use to come here with my boss for lunch on Wednesday for the twice baked potato, bbq chicken, and caesar salad.  Just make sure you are dressed appropriately for this environment (business casual), I've always found it to be a little uppity

yWvp2zxqgU1VaH6V5EjSiw.review_text: amazing desserts!! HUGE for not that much $$!   Classic sundae is great, but be sure to get multiple spoons!

upwcws-Jc1mOh1qSk_1YKg.review_text: My wife and I drove with our seven year old daughter to have dinner at Max's.  We live closer to many other restaurants that we would have chosen except for the fact that we had a coupon for $10 off dinner. The coupon's only parameters were that we spend over $20, the meal be after 5:00pm and only one discount per table. The coupon specifically listed two Max's locations which would honor the discount (one of which was this Van Ness location), and there was no expiration date.  You guessed it. We ate dinner (not cheap at nearly $90.00  with one kid's meal and one shared dessert ) and they said they were not going to honor the coupon. I pointed out that it had their specific location listed and that there was no expiration date. The waitress simply said, "We're not part of that group anymore". I said, "are you sure this is how you want to treat your customers?" She said "You can use it somewhere else". This after not being able to find her for a single coffee refill.   So Max, with all of your empty proclamations of "The customer is always right" etc on everything from napkins to banner boards hung on the wall, you would think that customer service would include honoring your own unexpired coupon, with your own address specified, and a photo of your own location's interior printed on its face. Sorry Max, you screwed up. You cost your waitress a tip, you cost yourselves goodwill, and irritated customers in the process.  I guess the economy hasn't hit your restaurant to the point that you care about chasing away customers.  These fast slipping Yelp reviews actually make a difference to many of us....be careful or your customers will all go away.

hDzHnCtQGsOOcKx1yb57cQ.review_text: Love love love Max's. Great atmosphere, delicious food,  drinks well mixed, and UNBELIEVABLE live performance. Seriously, I don't understand why all these hot men are waiting on the tables, when they clearly should be singing  Figaro at Bolshoi.   Make sure to try their pear salad while you there. Like an orgasm in your mouth

bWxxfPP08zWJuM5wKG0LvQ.review_text: We came here for a dessert after a sushi dinner. A word of advice, their desserts are huge much like everything else on the menu. My boyfriend and I split the hot fudge sundae and there was easily enough for four people. The menu here is vast and the service is rather interesting. The waiters and waitresses will take a break from serving you to break into song which is cool if you're into that sort of thing...on some nights I like my ice cream with a side of showtunes and on some nights I prefer my ice cream without.

m07sy7eLtOjVdZ8oN9JKag.review_text: "Figaro....Figaro, Figaro, Figaro!"...but if you hear opera live in an eatery, don't you think the place should have checkerboard tablecloths, melting candles in cheap Chianti bottles, and Lady and the Tramp mutually sucking their al dente spaghetti noodle?  It's funny how ambiance can truly make a difference for even a chain restaurant. In my opinion, the Max's near Union Square is dreadful from a service standpoint, as the attitudes have been fossilized from years of dealing with truculent tourists and squawking shoppers. Perhaps representing the gateway to the Tenderloin has hardened the staff into becoming gatekeepers of the socially acceptable.  Even though they have exactly the same menu at the same prices, I have to give one more star to Max's Opera Cafe because the staff is more genuine, some of whom actually sing at the piano whether we want them to or not. The opera connection seems outdated, but it still somehow works, probably because the interior still has that darkened 1970's, Peppermill-meets-Lyons kind of vibe. They just need their waitresses to wear Peppermill's backless, orange evening dresses when they  serve cocktails.  Last night, I shared a heaping slice of apple pie a la mode, which was a relative bargain compared to the $3 cup of coffee (that's where they grab ya). But I've had the Cobb Salad and the Reuben and all points dietically in between. Hefty portions and good while they last but a tendency to leave my memory bank soon after departure both from the restaurant and out of my...  FOOD - 3 stars...this must be the place all those news reports highlight to show how Americans are getting fatter by the minute AMBIANCE - 3 stars...all they need is a pimp in a lavender fedora SERVICE - 3.5 stars...friendlier than their battle-weary comrades near Union Square TOTAL - 3 stars...bel canto arias and belch bellowing sonatas

qoVIx35Fz5G3GUHllVRegw.review_text: When living in San Rafael from 1991 - 1994, I used to view a trip to Max's Opera Cafe as a major treat.  The food was amazing, the entertainment was fantastic, and the atmosphere was very cool.  After I moved out of state, the Peppermill in Corte Madera became a Max's.  D'oh!!  At that time, I would have given it 5 Stars.  After relocating to the Bay Area in 2000, I looked forward to returning to Max's Opera Cafe, but it seemed that the quality of the desserts had changed (possibly a different vendor) and the ingredients used were not the same.  Unfortunately, over time, their other locations near Moscone and the sandwich shop near the Embarcadero shut down.  Nowadays, I can enjoy it, but I have to lower my expectations and not compare it to Max's Opera Cafe, circa 1994.  Great place to go if you are near City Hall...  I would advise going right after the curtain goes up at the Ballet or they dim the lights at the Symphony.  That is best time to get a table, as the theatre crowd disappears and you can really realax.  Not sure what is going on with the quality...  they really seemed to take pride in the authenticity of their New York Deli style food in the 1990's.  Now, I can only give it 2 Stars and say "Meh.  I've experienced better." but, that better experience was from the SAME RESTAURANT.

GxQh8XQB54sxjDGjkC0zOQ.review_text: Being that my parents have been eating their Niagra Falls cake since I was in the womb, I have a soft spot for Max's.  I think its a totally fun experience and while the food is maybe not the most amazing I've ever had, it's fine enough to precede a night at the theater.  Not sure I can name favorites, but last time I had: Caesar Salad Max 'n' Cheese Niagra Falls Cake  And I'd happily eat any of it again!

MGiNuc2p089hX_Vy8JJQiw.review_text: The menu proclaims, "This is a bad place for a diet!"   But what an extraordinary place it is to bond, especially on a Friday or Saturday night!   Max's is a highly popular post-performance destination, and we always seem to fit right in.   When I visit, I am usually in the company of performers from the venues around Van Ness, and it's just as easy to mingle with other figures which frequent this place.   The desserts are divinity on Earth.  There isn't a single one that I don't recommend!   Max's uses singing waiters/waitresses, which adds an interesting touch to the whole experience.  Be sure to clap, even if they shattered a few wine glasses.   I hesitate to take a few of the other reviews of this place seriously, like the dork who can't even seem to remember what he ordered. Uh huh, just the way he likey.  That being said, there are a few items to avoid, such as the lip-peeling buffalo wing salad.  Just don't do it.   Also, the pasta isn't necessarily gourmet quality, but with so much else to order, why the hell are you eating pasta? Nearly everything else is deeply satisfying.    Just as Max's relies on the Civic Center's jewels (the symphony, the ballet, and the opera), these events just wouldn't be the same without Max's.

2giO3bs09uw0NDPU01sCvg.review_text: If you want comfort food this is the place for you!  Have the whole bowl of matzo ball soup.  Their wings are good too...who cares that it's a geriatric crowd their portions are big and the price is right.  Reminds me of a good 'ole Jewish deli growing up in Jersey.

jJZJsUSfPdtFgllH23HxqQ.review_text: HORRIBLE!!! YOU WILL CRY!!! Horrible service. We got ignored for most of the time.  Menu prices are outrageous. And the menu choices...? A bunch of dishes that don't strike the fancy.  The nachos were nothing like nachos. I guess you shouldn't order nachos at a diner by the SF Opera.  Never going back!! EVER!

mAwm8AletAsn5URUOTjUEw.review_text: Came here prior to attending "Wicked" at Orpheum Theatre despite the distance, as no decent restaurants were nearby there.  It turned out to be a good choice.  The place was busy, but we got seated within 15 minutes.  There is a full liquor bar where you can sit and wait for your table. YWRt731Ydv8na5DohxqynQ.review_text: Seriously awful food. In a foodie town you can do better.  Max's is a chain restaurant that serves fatty, expensive appetizers, and bland deli food in glutton-sized portions. The salads could use more greens, especially for the price.  The brisket melt sandwich was terribly soggy and drippy, and fell apart immediately. The beef was mushy and lacked flavor. The bread was barely grilled. The Ceaser side salad was miniscule and had far too much dressing.  The chicken Cobb salad had decently fresh ingredients (the tomatoes were very flavorful), but needed more greens.  The 'fresh crusty bread' was previously-frozen oven warmed rolls that were chewy and overly sweet.  The prices are not cheap, even by San Francisco standards: Appetizers run $9-$14, sandwiches are $13-20 ($13 for a grilled cheese!) salads run $13-$18, and you'll pay $17 for a chicken pot pie.  One bright spot: The service was pleasant and low key.  You can find better deli for less money, or if you want to spend $50 for lunch there are SO many places you can dine - not just eat.

In the meantime, eat at Tommy's Joynt, also on Van Ness Avenue. It's cheaper and dirtier, but at least it's an authentic San Francisco sandwich/hofbrau. Skip Max's Opera Cafe until the management eats their own food. They'll probably curl up and die!

Ih1kkaqEMhlNf4E2k6E_ng.review_text: We've been going to Max's Opera Cafe for about five years now, and have always enjoyed the ambiance there.  It's a bright corner on Van Ness, with large windows facing the street and a lively atmosphere inside.  However, I have to say that the quality seems to have slipped, and on our last couple of visits, we found the food lacking.  First, the menu itself is much smaller.  Maybe the management wants to concentrate on the quality of fewer items, but the tastes don't seem to bear that out.  It also contradicts our expectations of delis with huge menus.  More to the point, their corned beef and pastrami, usually the signature ingredients of Jewish-style delis, were lacking.  The pastrami is apparently grilled, and the corned beef seemed like it came from a loaf of some kind.  Both meats just didn't have the flavors we savor, especially in a $13 sandwich.  Frankly, those meats are more flavorful at Tommy's Joynt up the street, and at half the price!  Perhaps the difference lies in the fact that Tommy's keeps those meats hot and moist on a steam table and hand carves them for each sandwich.  I hope that Max's will reconsider their approach to these sandwiches and entice us back again with an improved dining experience.

enl_Tk2hGIF6QpQDKDQ_2Q.review_text: It was peak time when we went and the host was less than welcoming...not off to a great start. A 30 min seating wait did allow for me to drool over the desserts...more on that later.   Shrimp cocktail had a decent amount of succulent morsels, but anyone can open a bag of cooked shrimp and throw out come cocktail sauce. Bistro salad was ok. Steak was good---topped with VILE fried onions--and I'm NEVER one to turn my nose up at fried foods. EVER. They were stale, cold, and I'm wondering if they left out the onions? Cold, thick creamed spinach.   Ok, so why 3 stars? The Reuben!! The sauce really does run down your hands! That won me over...a bit fatty though.  There's 5.4% "benefits" charge added to your bill in addition to sales tax (almost 10% these days) and then a 15-20% tip ? Well...you do the math.   I did have another Reuben at Mel's Diner for $5 less (not including Max's added charges!!) and dare I say it--it was comparable.   The desserts however looked quite delicious, but I wasn't wearing my elasticized pants at the time so I reluctantly passed on that round.

avcQbkVRQ0skWZS1rkoAQg.review_text: We ate here before going to the opera to see Show Boat.  The food was "okay" - but nothing to rave about.  Mostly, it is a zoo to watch elderly people eating their food.  The table next to us sported an unhappy customer who demanded to see the manager to complain about the waiter's ability to service his table.  The place was very crowded and the waiters were literally running with food to service the tables.  I thought about how the wait staff must hate "Opera Night" to see all these grouchy old people come in complaining and demanding because they never get out and because they get shocked at the prices of the food.  This, of course, has little to do with Max's Opera Cafe - but if you like watching old rich people act foolish, this might be just the place you want to go.

17mIfDdKLcS9X0NBBEWGfw.review_text: Max's is a staple of the Civic Center area. For a late night dessert, it's a popular place.  For lunch, it's a popular place. Heck, for dinner it's a popular place. This particular location has gone through a recent remodel. It's a bit more "diner" feel now with blacks and whites being a central color theme. Menu hasn't changed much though prices have gone up slightly.  The food is pretty consistent and usually fairly large in portion though you'll find newer items on the menu will usually start off with larger portions and then are pared down the longer they stay on the menu.  I'm particularly partial to the meat loaf, enchilada pie (which is usually a special), chicken pot pie (which has gotten smaller over time), and the turkey burger max.  For salads, give a try to Guy's Chinese Chicken salad though go for a half unless you are really hungry.  In the evenings the waitpeople also double as entertainment and will go up and sing with the pianst.  They started charging an extra surcharge for the evenings so expect a somewhat pricier dinner than you might be used to from a Max's.  For lunch, which is primarily when I go there (since I work in the area), I definitely recommend getting there at least 10 minutes before noon to beat the lunch crowd, especially during the holidays when afternoon performances of "The Nutcracker" are going on nearby and the restaurant is filled with families eating lunch prior to the show.  Overall, it's one of the better places around the Civic Center area and worth a visit or two.  Remember to save room for dessert!

jyHW1rFxcoJ8gYBmcyk-FA.review_text: Ginormous menu.  Seriously it takes me about 15 min. to even narrow down what I am going to get here.  Am always happy with whatever I end up going with.  I love their Rye Bread and they have a good selection of soups and sandwiches too.

2Qfa3o72sq04_MCUxy3Shg.review_text: The Story of the Time I Got Carded in the Rudest Way:  I volunteer every wednesday at PJOH (holla!) and last wednesday, two of my co volunteers who are serving as pseudo moms pleasantly decided to take me here for a drink. kap-a51yfAh4HeJFlHMS7A.review_text: Big portions and decent pricing, especially since they are a restaurant inside the Opera Plaza and so near the Superior Court/City Hall.  They can overcharge you, but they don't.  Burgers here are of course decent.  Don't order the fries b/c it's not that good, unless you are desperate.  The crab cakes are pretty good due to the tartar sauce that comes with it.  I can dip anything into that sauce.  Their philly cheese steak is good too b/c they do not go cheap on the cheese.  Patty melt.. hm... tons of grease, just like how it's meant to be.  Their salads aren't that great though.  $6 for a ceasars and the romaine lettuce aren't that crispy, and their caesars dressing are only mediocre.

TDxd9HHzB1m4QOy1mPE-qA.review_text: Delicious! I highly recommend Max's because the food is heavenly. Here are my ratings/reviews for all the food that I have eaten here.   Prime Rib and Creamed Spinach - 5/5 Stars!  The prime rib was extremely tender, just the way I like it. It was accompanied excellently with the creamed spinach which had a nice tang of cream.    Dungeness Crab Cakes - 5/5 Stars!  Exquisite! Hands down my favorite food on the menu. The inside of the crab cakes are superb. The combination of the juicy crab with the crunchy crab shell is just sensational. The crab cakes are hard to beat..  Caesar Salad - 4/5 Stars  4/5 stars is not bad for one of my favorite salads. I am a caesar salad lover and its hard to impress me. The dressing and croutons were decent although the dressing could be a tad bit richer with a bit more dijon mustard or worcestershire sauce. That combined with maybe a bit fresher romaine lettuce leaves and it would certainly bring it up to 5 stars.   Chicken Caesar Wrap - 3/5 Stars  Not bad. It's a convenient food that you can take on the run and its pretty tasty. The only thing is that it's a little heavy on the sauce. If they just put a little less sauce on it, it would be perfect!  Chicken Liver - 3/5 Stars  Tasted just the way I thought. Some people love it and can eat it by the spoon. Me personally, I am not a huge fan but its typical of chicken liver anywhere else. It's just not my cup of tea.  Omelette - 4/5 Stars  I came here for breakfast once and I got the omelette with mushrooms, spinach, tomatoes, and a side of chicken sausage. It was decent and I would definitely recommend coming here for breakfast. It's also perfect for hangovers :)  Matzah Ball Soup - 3/5 Stars  I know people that go crazy over this and love it to death. Nothing too special about it except its great on a cold day.   Lamb Burger - 5/5 Stars!  Lamb... so yummy. Enough said..  Ahi Tuna - 4/5 Stars  Ahi Tuna, I almost forgot! It was crusted and seasoned with sesame which had a nice tangy spike to it. I personally thought the ahi tuna was very tender which is great.  Grandma's Honey Chicken - 5/5 Stars!  One of my top 3 favorites. This meal was perfect. The glazed honey sauce contrasting with the tender seasoned chicken was divine.. I would highly recommend this!  Overall, I've had great experiences with Max's. Dungenes crab cakes takes the cake for being top-notch. The crispness of the crab cake is potent and unmatched. The servers are extremely friendly and the vibe is nice. Can't wait to come again!

k4h5VRMWiKzWYPDW1gLj6A.review_text: HUGE. i like any place where the waiters will sing gershwin. the latkes were good. the matzo ball soup was ok. only 1 guy at our table (we had about 15 people) finished. it's a bit too much, especially as my friend had an entire slab of blue cheese on her salad - that's unneccesary and hard to eat.

eL9CR1oxghmW8MyP5duxbw.review_text: The singing can be a bit . . .twee, but the potato pancakes are fantastic.  I echo everyone elses' comments about the portions large enough for a family of four. Frequently crowded, so go early or late.

AjinOqTsVOtm72fO88D1Ww.review_text: This is my favorite place to have a nice filling meal prior to the ballet or Broadway shows. eCcjxh8zjAqn-kZVWZ_HJQ.review_text: Long before I moved here my family would visit SF for Christmas shopping around the holidays.  Because the location was conveniently close to Union Square, and because my sisters and I loved the "Laws", we would always come to Max's to eat.  I haven't been recently, but from what I remember the food was good and the atmosphere was fun.

i3IHt5GDKUyF4_Zax2R71g.review_text: I like this place for its convenience for dinners after attending the Opera or Symphony. The food is good. AT6NwNkLKxgW2fsQGNs-gA.review_text: By far, my favorite Max's -- home of gi-normous portions, comfort food as far as the eye can see, and desserts that give me 'the diabetes' just by looking at them. What sets this one apart is the atmosphere, as you see a lot of pre-symphony/operetta goers, so it just feels more elegant. And I don't know about you, but I get a thrill when someone is delivering my food one minute and then bringing down the house with a rousing rendition of "I Like New York In June" the next, given most of the servers are aspiring singers who work there in order to take turns showcasing their talented windpipes.

qJaBmnhTvZwZTsrCaiVWkQ.review_text: Max's ultimate chocolate cake is phenomenon.  I came here only for chocolate cake.  Therefore, my review is only for dessert nothing else.  Just a note the whole ultimate chocolate cake can serve up to 30 people because it is very big and rich.

a2E50HoU89NLZvh1YP8fgA.review_text: It's sad to say that everything here is going downhill: first their chicken now their matzo ball soup =( I was feeling like sh!t and wanted some good soup but was so disappointed when I got it. Wow what's happening to this place?? Food downhill, prices sky high...no good!

TKQpDyK3ZQcDFM2Hjde-Cw.review_text: Max's is a cross between a diner and a nice American restaurant. The ambiance is fun and great for groups, especially those coming from or going to a nearby show. The waiters take turns singing to everyone with live piano accompaniment, which my friend and i greatly enjoyed.  The menu is quite extensive so everyone will find something they enjoy. I liked the witty list of "Max's laws" printed on the menu and throughout the restaurant.  One law mentioned how Max's prepares freshly brewed iced tea table side. Since I'm a huge iced tea fan, I had to try this and was delighted when our waiter brought me two large glasses filled with ice and a small tea pot. The result - it was one of the best iced teas I've ever had and I got to make it myself, which was a fun activity while we were waiting for food to arrive.  I ordered the salmon with veggies - prepared well and not overcooked. My friend got the HUGE chicken pot pie. While he liked it, he felt it was too meat heavy for his taste and didn't have enough gravy. I tried some and thought it was delicious, although I agree with there not being enough gravy.  For dessert I got the Fantasy Torte after drooling over it in the display case. It's a layered mix of cheesecake, chocolate mousse, and chocolate cake - all surrounded by a layer of thick chocolate fudge. Simply amazing. If for nothing else, Max's is a great place to come for dessert.  While the food was pretty good and the dessert oh-so-yummy, the poor service really left us with a so-so experience. Our waiter rarely attended to us besides taking our order and handling our check. We had to ask other waiters passing by for drink refills multiple times. One waiter apologized for our inattentive waiter, and I could tell looking around the room that the other waiters were doing a better job keeping their tables happy. I'm sure we had an unusual experience, but for now that's why Max's gets only 3 stars instead of 4.

rCIK8lUIMgfdKs8jYl_Hww.review_text: I used to come here before or after symphony, ballet, opera and really thought the food was great. However, last night we ate here before the ballet, and it was an epic fail. I asked the waitress about an item on the menu "bricked chicken and garlic confit" and she was clueless, saying it was a baked half chicken with some garlic. She didn't know what confit meant for this dish and didn't offer to find out.  So I ordered the chicken piccata. It was AWFUL. It was FRIED, like coated with something and FRIED. It did not mention "fried" on the menu. I would never have ordered it if it did. And: It was overcooked, dry and chewy. The sauce, which is supposed to be lemony, was pretty tasteless except for the capers. I couldn't eat it.  The wild rice pilaf might have been tasty if it weren't so super salty. I could barely eat it.  The sautéed spinach (I love spinach) was so bitter that I literally couldn't eat it.   My friend ordered the same thing. Maybe I need to stick with pastrami sandwiches and chopped liver? I don't know. But I won't be going back any time soon!

9KRi3zWRtv9u9pDATeRPOA.review_text: The service was very good and the food is always consistent. I have never had the best meal of my life here, but I have never had a bad meal either. The piano playing added just the right ambiance to our Valentine Dinner.

Fu0eC8gxkXzrMxSZHdJN2A.review_text: Waitress inattentive, order incorrect, generally a "we will never return" experience.

omkrjazjotwQHtqmmumFeg.review_text: omg i love this place... the fact that i can get a uber huge meal at midnight  is such a draw... i haven't been to the one downtown, but they have one in burlingame, and i meet up with my friends there all the time... perfect for young professionals who work late, but still have the energy to meet up with friends to catch up on life... relaxed, friendly atmosphere makes it easy to forget the day's stresses...

Ld4u1I2_OnjrXxazjw4mwQ.review_text: You had a bad day, lost your best friend, your cat died.  This is the place for you!  Have a bowl of matzo ball soup, some rye bread and butter, crispy iceberg lettuce salad, petrale sole, and a chocolate eclair.  Use Waiters on Wheels to deliver to your cave or park in the underground and pick up.  It's enough for two meals.

sfQXLZGk6beiSuNZYb8iSQ.review_text: HUGE portions, SERIOUSLY!!! Food's pretty good though, nothing GREAT yet descent, full bar which definitely helps! One Thurs night was a nice surprise though. owt0p6Z4iZ6ylvbMWIO-qw.review_text: We had our sites set on dessert and Max's turned out be an A+ choice.  The location is perfect, right on the corner of Geary and Van Ness Ave in the City.  Everything looked scrumptious on the menu.  The fries are hand cut and the burgers also looked divine.  The place was bumpin' with a crowd of twenty-and thirty somethings.  There were two tables of people from Germany and France surrounding us (I always enjoy picking out familiar phrases from the days when I studied French!).    There's nothing like a huge crock of cranberry apple cobbler to mask the oily, slimy film of fatty pho (big mistake choosing to dine in China town beforehand...).  The desserts were absolutely phenomenal.  The hot-fudge sundae is spot on, as are the pies.  Want something to go?  Grab a full size pumpkin pie for around $12.95.   What a deal!  They are also no-sugar added options for the health-conscious individual like myself.    But, I was on vacation and wanted to splurge.  This cobbler was out of a dream.  The ratio between crust and filling was prime, and the scoop of vanilla ice cream on top added just the right amount of creaminess to balance the cranberries' tartness.  I could go on forever about this treat.  The service could have been a little swifter, but I wasn't in a rush.  Another hit in the heart of the city.

YXqAy0Bmvcl5ZmRa_ANCAA.review_text: Always a nice meal, generous helpings and tasty food. Fun place to go.

oM7HuPqYgjTgVcNWr5jaRA.review_text: We were at the San Francisco symphony recently and some of our friends invited us to Max's. The location was great as it is pretty close to symphony hall. We ordered roast beef sandwitch, pastas and jambalaya. The food was O.K. We also ordered vanilla ice cream for desert. The service was fast. The dishes were priced reasonably low for San Francisco. I would go back to this place if I was around in the neighborhood.

eRwM7aFGKM_dJLUvjYX3tg.review_text: I came here the other night after the opera with my family. We come here pretty ofteen to both this location and the one around union square. They have the best rueben sandwiches, my favorite being the pastrami and corn beef with swiss cheese and thousand island dressing. WIth every every sandwich you get  to choose from three side dishes: coleslaw, potato salad or cucumber salad.     If you are into show tunes, some of the staff sing a few tunes during dinner time.

x4D4K54gL54E6Sv_OXalwA.review_text: I would recommend this place for desserts, but not for the main course. Food was mediocre. Service was ok.  Great place to go on a date for dessert because on the weekends there are usually singings.

tCbdbNU4naCDgTkxriU4VQ.review_text: Went here recently for my mom's 80th birthday and didn't have a good experience.  There were 9 of us and we were put in a corner in the back and received very poor and somewhat rude service.  We had to ask for things twice and some things never came so we just made sure they didn't bill us for the missing things.  Food was average but not especially fresh and tasty.  I have been coming here with smaller parties for over 20 years with much better service and food so I'm wondering what happened.  I might give them one more chance and then skip them in the future.  We gave them the standard required tip but probably should have asked them to take that off the tab.  We didn't because we just wanted to get out of there.

vgwdQ0fpDZdoTidJuwYq7w.review_text: Max is seriously out of control! Whoever he is, he could learn a thing or two about portion size. Jews don't really eat like that, do they? PsAuKhmBsMQFQc80uCL0uQ.review_text: Good spot, good food, and amazing Rye Bread, definitely get a loaf of the California Caraway Rye to take home.  Nice location, but nothing to special about it.

EGfQMYMxnUDmSdsXhXDoxA.review_text: I like going here for dessert. The waiters/waitresses sing with the piano every now and then. They must be aspiring actor/tresses or singers. RRaC4FsLEpxNo5Xd3F4iTw.review_text: Slightly above average American food with huge portions. The menu covers a pretty wide spectrum, I opted for the chicken pot pie. AHz3sGxkZjAzv8uu0Q9hqg.review_text: I think that any place that shares the name of my orange tabby can't be too bad...  I've been to Max's at the Opera in the past and it is pretty predictable.  Yet, this time, it wasn't so predictable.  I hadn't realized that it changed ownership, but the menu has also taken a drastic turn.    So, this is what I have to say:  $40.00 for lunch for 2 is ludicrous. m5cBT7OYfn0HM0d-RCsdZQ.review_text: redundant  Been here too many times after the opera with old dates for their apple pie a la mode, served warm. bqLH4pqxYabHs9X8KskLpw.review_text: Yah it's a tourist trap. So what? You're probably from Iowa too; you just lost the denim shorts and the United We Stand shirt. Afq57_KYVBBJlSj1X5-4xQ.review_text: This place has the air of an institution. And while that lends historical context, and a monster of a menu, the word "dated" readily applies. Noone will debate that food quantity is American-style "copious". Nor  mince words that a live piano, multiple lo-slung chandeliers and a lounge singer who doubles as intermittent server doesn't equal a unique offering. 8TdJ4bTZazpvZXkjWCpxOA.review_text: Although I discovered Max's serves decent sliders and a pretty good clam chowder, the service was subpar today.  At Max's establishments, there is a list of Laws the staff is not supposed to break.  At least three of them were broken today.    It started with the burger sliders which were described on the menu as coming with crispy onion strings.  When the sliders arrived, they were draped with RAW dehydrated wilty red onion strings.  My friend and I were confused because the red onions sure as heck didn't look fried.  This was when Law #16 was broken, because the server is supposed to check-in with us within four minutes of serving the entrees.  So... the one time something is wrong, I couldn't locate anyone on the staff to tell.  I decided to ask the girl serving water if the red onions were the crispy onion strings and she stared at me like I was speaking Martian and said "I don't know" and walked away without a look back.  A few minutes later, I managed to flag down our waitress to ask the same question.  Apparently, she didn't know either, because she ended up taking our dish away to the kitchen and mumbled something about the kitchen possibly having run out of crispy onion strings.  Huh?  If that was the case, shouldn't she have told us in the first place so we could have ordered something else? I'd recommend stopping in for dessert and drinks in the late evening. I LOVE the Niagara Falls cake-- chocolate cake with loads of white butter-cream frosting. So worth the sugar coma it induces! Also, the brownie sundae is heaven as well. Mmmmmm I think my blood sugar is spiking just thinking about it!  Thirdly, as said in other reviews, yes, most of the portions are HUGE. I can only eat half of that chicken pot pie. It's good to come here and split an appetizer and an entree with someone (unless you're one of those who enjoys having a muffin-top, of course).   They have a lot of different kinds of salads, which are, again, huge, and they are popular too. Their burgers are mediocre-- I wouldn't waste your money on one from here. Their pastrami sandwiches seem to be popular too, but that's not my cup of tea, so I couldn't tell ya!  Also, to be noted-- it gets super crowded here when there is an opera/performance, especially in December with the Nutcracker going on. There are loads of children running around. If you're like me, you'll avoid those times like the plague. :D  Last thing to say-- they don't take reservations, so if you come here on a weekend night, especially on a "performance" night, you should probably be prepared to wait a while.

bAnzGRGuXxtiL-RTsb98pQ.review_text: Pretty impressive. All waitstaffs know how to sing. The food is typical american cuisine. Whenever I come to Max's, i can only order 1 item because the food portions are so huge.They serve king size sandwiches, gigantic salads, hot comfort food, and homogous desserts. They are definately not measly with the food. I had the double chicken marsala. It was delicious. Service is pretty good too.

wL2m84Os2YcQy_LLL0PIkg.review_text: Sunday Brunch at Max's is a noisy affair, but you can tolerate that if they still have Brunch...not so, even if you arrive within the stated hours it might be all gone, as was my experience with simple scrambled eggs!

L_0U7hoo2tVzjmPAwLss6w.review_text: Uncomfortably loud and crowded, with dismally slow service. Wooden painted tables are not level so glasses slide toward one corner; chairs crammed in so tight that everyone has to get up for anyone to get out. Long line for 2-stall ladies room with no paper towel and decrepit air dryers. Tempted to walk across the street to McDs for something to eat while waiting, or for an adequately cooked burger - Max's "medium well" is raw in the middle. Reserved for 12 2 weeks in advance but still seated at 2 tables. Neglected and neglectful, poor value.

nlOxarS20luHkAloH5YyzA.review_text: I love music and I love food.  Put them together and you've got Max's Opera Cafe.  Very large selection of food on their menu.  I love their nachos!  Great desserts.  They have huge chocolate covered macaroons which are yummy with a side of ice cream.   Great place for lunch or dinner, except they don't sing at lunch time.  Always dependable for a good meal.  Not very expensive either.

1_E9Eqny_AAm_i_iuKWlVQ.review_text: A friend and I visited Max's on a super cold, rainy night for a cocktail while we waited for some of our friend's to come around.  I was very pleased with my experience and would definitely come back. FjNgN6Dk9fh4NatwthoFgA.review_text: Decent food, but not the best for your buck.

h_D5bOae1GPKkkOChyuSmQ.review_text: Not sure what happened to Max's.  Max's was a staple for me and my friends since moving to SF in 2002.  I've been to five of the locations: San Bruno, Oakland, Opera, Union square, and 3rd Street SOMA.  However, over the past three years the prices have increased and the quality of the food has declined.  Service has always been spotty depending on time of day.  About 6 months ago I finally swore this place off for good.

Z7cS9nxugC69XY77zZjTFg.review_text: This is the most overrated place ever.  I used to live in Opera Plaza, so I'd go to Max's and keep thinking, "Well, maybe last time was just a fluke..."  but no, consistently mediocre-to-bad service, mediocre food for the price, etc.  Now that I don't live there, I would never consider going out of my way to eat there.

AkJW29QzZXdGhP1YYSw3UQ.review_text: We had only one hour before the opera and it was very good for the occasion.

eUmVXP9UnoWtz9NSBwY4jA.review_text: I'm not sure if it was too much 4th of July fun or the ever changing weather but I've felt like crap all week.  Who the hell gets sick in July? Next time you're feeling lousy or are just looking for a good cesar, give Max's a shot.

Uk-PA5mk2A8NMjRdeBYJiw.review_text: Great place to grab a bite to eat before the Symphony or Opera, complete with their own piano and singers (that may double as your waiter/waitress). If you haven't been here and can't decide what sandwich to get you MUST try their Max's Famour Reuben Sandwich. Their corned beef and pastrami is packed with flavor and you can get a mix of both if you really can't decide. It's a big sandwich, so come with an appetite and comes complete with warm swiss cheese and sauerkraut. And their fries trumps their potato salad hands down, so order your sandwich with fries!

SPbdGX1c5q2UoFngJJVvRQ.review_text: Ew, I think we hit this Max's on an off-night. Ks3mctocVtBj-AHjKx1PLg.review_text: I had a terrible "never should happen" experience today at Max's near the Civic Center.  They lost my credit card!  How does that happen?  The waiter brought us our check and I put our credit card in the small pocket intended for it.  No one came by for quite a while but when they finally did, they said the card was lost.  We had ballet tickets so we agreed they would still look for it while we were at the ballet.  When we  returned 2 1/2 hours later, they had not found the card.  They were nice enough to pick up our lunch (the least I would expect) but did not even offer a gift card for all the hassle we now face with canceling our card, calling numerous businesses that have our credit card on file, etc.  Nor did they offer to pay for our parking...but they were kind enough to let us know where there was an ATM.  I was shocked as was my 12 year old daughter. THbxu0ynyjIJf8elEQtqdQ.review_text: Great location. Huge portions but the food is n othing special. If you are in the mood for something plain and American, it's a great place.  I had lunch here with a big group and it was a perfect place for that.

i3K-OgFAAEx2UpUZ95cpkg.review_text: I've always liked Max's ever since I was a kid.  There are multiple locations in the Bay Area, but this one is my favorite.  The waiters will often sing (sometimes accompanied by piano) as many of them are working there as a side job while also performing across the street at the San Francisco Opera.  The menu is huge, giving tons of options from big salads, sandwiches, steaks, etc.  I love the club sandwich and turkey burger.  Huge portions too, so do not fill up on bread (even though the cinnamon raisin roll is awesome).

qICmFxBsuQblIhOSgE_y9Q.review_text: This review breaks my heart.  Max's is such awesome food and the piano bar is such a great idea.  I've made it my life's mission to find the perfect Rueben Sandwich and Max's is the closest I've come.  But let's be honest here:  The evening service sucks.    There is a long tradition of show biz people working in restaurants.  Singing wait staff is not difficult to find in San Francisco.  That said, these people are performers and could at least 'act' like they want to help you.  I tip 20%+ for exceptional service, 15% for standard.  We've only stiffed one person in the past ten years, and that was Max's waitress.  She was horrible.  She told us she would be back with our drinks and a busboy delivered water.  Fifteen minutes later a busboy came and took our order.  Okay...I've waited tables before...maybe she's on break?  Maybe they could tell us?  The place was busy, but it certainly wasn't slammed.   Then yet another busboy brought us our food.  She wandered back and forth past our table, yet didn't acknowledge us during the entire meal.  Never came up and asked us how we were doing and I had to track down a mustard caddy for my sandwich.  Finally she approached with our check while the dirty dishes congealed on the table, gave us a cursory nod, and wandered off.  That was it.  On a fifty dollar bill, she should have received a minimum of a $7.50 tip.  She got nothing.  She was there the second the money was in the billfold and stood there as we exited shooting daggers from her eyes.  I met her stare and I must say I was extremely angry with her.  If I'm paying $20 for a sandwich and a soft drink, I expect service.  This was not an isolated incident, merely the most severe one.  I've had some occasions where I've had the one seemingly good wait person in the evening and she was an absolute delight.  The lunch staff is a little more enthusiastic than the evening staff, and the evening staff is, by and large, under the impression that we need them more than they need us.  All of this aside, Max's food is typically very good.  I just don't recommend this particular location for the evening crowd.

8T_sbIjItVWJ43DcSbmXRw.review_text: It's obvious to us now that not all Max's are the same when it comes to food quality and quantity, even though they are franchise restaurants.  This is our third and definitely last time dining here.    On the first visit, we ordered their signature chicken pot pie.  It arrived with 25% of the crust obviously burnt, yet the waiter served the dish anyway.  Needless to say, we asked for a replacement and, after some time, the waiter returned with what was obviously the old pie reassembled and this time with a smaller crust covering and less filling.  That was a major disappointment, but we decided to give them another chance.    On our second visit, they were again not very good, as the pie lacked enough gravy to keep the chicken moist, so let's say it was like chicken pot "cookie."  We therefore decided against ordering the chicken pot pie on our third and final visit.      I first have to say that we would not have ordinarily chosen Max (Van Ness) after the two dissatisfying dinners, but we had a show to attend that was close by and timing was essential.  This time however, we decided to order something different, as we figured the chicken pot pie would be another disappointment.  In its place, we ordered the overpriced (half slab for $19) ribs and tri-mushroom pasta.    The pasta was tasty and similar to other Max restaurants, except the quantity appeared less.  As for the ribs, they were cooler than room temperature and the BBQ sauce was a last minute spread that was also not heated.  Worse yet, the meat did not fall off the bone as they should, so obviously undercooked.  There's something about having to use fork and knife to eat ribs that really did not sit well with good old BBQ food.  We won't be patronizing this place unless everything else close by is closed or too busy, and we do not have time to wait; otherwise, we'll continue to patronize Max's on GEARY BLVD instead where their chicken pot pie is consistently excellent, as well as there many other dishes that we tried.  One would think that the restaurant manager here at Van Ness would have concerns about the overall (under 3 stars) reviews, but guess he believes his is irreplaceable.

PBkUgCtHyauuaOr5FSSyTg.review_text: I love coming here after watching a performance close-by.  I've always liked the atmosphere and the waiters/waitresses who sing is just great.  Service is always good.  The food..  We're here to eat right?  Great and sometimes HUGE portions.  A normal meal will be between $20 - $30.  Totally worth it.

I wonder if anyone there has even eaten it, I doubt it.

Sadfir42vt64m_AWV18WLA.review_text: The 4 stars are for the desserts alone, which are really decadent and served in rather large portions.  I had a slice of Max's cake, and also got bites of their chocolate cake and their brownie.  The chocolate cake was delicious and very moist, while my cake was almost too rich to eat.  The brownie was okay, though it initially came out with the wrong toppings.  The hot fudge was delicious though.  Service was not bad, but I couldn't understand their rather strange service "rules."  I want to be asked if "how everything is" because that's usually when I get the chance to let the server know whether I need something or not.    In any case, all the desserts were really good- I'd come back for those desserts and possibly some of their main courses.  The singing is a little distracting, especially when you're trying to have a conversation, but it was neat to listen to the servers belt their hearts out.

0XXIv9a0LWiaCjAkurjMMQ.review_text: Max's is some kind of New York import, but I'm not sure what kind.  The restaurant rules on the back of the menu guarantee a good customer experience.    My first Max's Opera Cafe experience was down by the airport, around 1997.  The waitstaff really did sing opera, and I hear they still do it at the Opera Plaza location.     I don't have to look at the menu when I go to Max's.  I want the Reuben sandwich.  These things are HUGE.  The longer they stand on your plate, the more the dressing soaks into the rye bread, but the crust stays crispy all the way through.  About 1/2 lb. of corned beef is the centerpiece of this sandwich, and the sauerkraut is just a little sour.  The last couple of times I have visited, I couldn't finish the sandwich.  Three sides came with it this time, but for me it is all about the sandwich.  I ordered a diet Coke to go along with it, and the waiter made sure there was always a glass on the table for me.    My Lady, who is more sensible than I, ordered a small Cobb salad and tea.  All four items cost us $31.71 + tip.  The waiter was surprisingly gracious, and earned a big tip.    There's a small deli counter at the front door, but I've never tried it.  There is only one Max's experience for me.

RKp356JpG3IIbTrmVFoRhg.review_text: I used to love to go to Max's. It is near work. The food used to be excellent and outstanding. Service is always A+  Don't know if they are having chef or cooking staff problems or whatever. They redecorated the one at the Opera Plaza. While the ambiance is still good, the food has slipped a bit. Don't crave it anymore like I used to. Hope they can step it up soon.

YtLGnLHSlE7Rg7N78FyGXA.review_text: Here's the thing: I ate at Max's before a show at Davies Symphony Hall, and you can't beat it for the proximity. I probably would have given it three stars then: Our sliders were a bit greasy, but the sweet potato fries were good and, even with a drink each we got out for under $30 in less than 45 minutes.  But I went recently for a friend's birthday and felt like I got scammed. For a glass of wine and a dessert, I ended up paying $25. After spending the equivalent on two stiff drinks and appetizers down the street at Olive, this seemed way overpriced.   Verdict: If you need a pre-theater bite to eat, go for it and literally stomach the prices. If not, check out the local eateries in nearby Hayes Valley -- or toddle on up to some cheaper eats with the fast food venues and Naan-N-Curry on Van Ness.

HshIhF76Uea0-2ht_KUisw.review_text: If I were a swinging member of the geriatric crowd- aspiring to hold the record for morbid obesity- with a handsome (expendable) lump of cash from the craps table in Reno (not Vegas) and owned a wardrobe exclusively from Talbots, Casual Corner and Just My Size (JMS), then, perhaps, I would consider visiting Max's a second time.

IRL8-4FCEz8KJ1C94SpXOA.review_text: Big hearty portions of everything, so be prepared to be stuffed at the end of your meal. P2fXcmsU_vrs4zB2IfsHnQ.review_text: Great place but come if you're hungry! They serve big portions! You'll enjoy the food and have a great time!

sebw6InCGlZseY4IByWynw.review_text: I miss the Jewish delis in LA but this is a good alternative. Matzo ball soup and latkes- YUM! what else do u need?
