Eql29rFLwZqvXbWMOuLloA.review_text: Turkey on rye, with lettuce tomato cheese and mayonnaise.  How inattentive do you have to be to screw that up?  For the record, this review is specific to the walk-up takeout counter at Max's.  I've eaten in the dining room before and never had a problem, but after today's experience I wonder.  There was no line at the counter when I ordered my sandwich.  When I got back to my desk and unwrapped the sandwich, the first thing I notice was the mustard.  I didn't order mustard on my sandwich, but it isn't the end of the world, so I tucked in.    The next thing I noticed was the cheese.  The slice of cheese had obviously been exposed to the air for too long, because a one-inch band along one edge had become indistinguishable from plastic.  I looked at the other half of the sandwich and saw...mayonnaise, not mustard.  Now, I'm not aware of there being a condiment equivalent to an Arnold Palmer, so the fact that she smeared half of a slice of bread with mustard and the other half of the same slice of bread with mayonnaise is somewhat of a puzzlement.  I never uttered the word "mustard" while placing my order, and certainly never invited the sandwich maker to follow her bliss and do something artistic on my bread with the contrasting colors of mayonnaise and mustard.  I can only surmise that she realized her mistake after she began smearing mustard on the bread and, instead of starting over with a new piece of bread, corrected her mistake on half of the bread.  By this point, I had completely lost confidence in the sandwich.  I ate the chips which, having been made by someone else, were pretty good.  Did I return to Max's and allow them a chance to get my sandwich right?  No.  I don't have sufficient time for lunch to accommodate a return trip to a restaurant that messes up a simple lunch order.  Get the freakin order right, or don't expect the customer to come back.

iJIwz_f3-uC8a7dP-6LX7g.review_text: I've had many good meals from Max's, but we just had a truly dreadful brisket plate and was really disappointed.

g-oxsda0wMjKgIoXXrZlQA.review_text: Great place...you just have to be in the mood for a LOT of food.    - I heart grilled cheese and theirs is soooooo tasty...maybe a little overpriced though at $12 or so.   - Their chicken salad wrap is excellent and not overly huge.   - Reuben is De-lic-ious.   - Love the live piano player and occasional singer in the evenings.    - The pot pie was just way tooo big and nothing special.  I had to drench it with hot sauce.   - Really good overall but there are better places.

inqvdMiUvgzipbwJgI0ckw.review_text: Went there after attending a performance at the Symphony Friday night. Blomstedt did a brilliant job conducting.   I find it a little disconcerting to have to walk through what feels like a pickup area to get to the Host. The restaurant feels a little run down but I do like the lighting fixtures.   I had a nice glass of the house Chardonnay. Hubby drank his usual water, which was brought to the table promptly as was the bread and butter. Nice thing about the butter was that it wasn't rock hard as most butter in restaurants is. I had a small order of nachos which were quite good with lots of different items on them like black beans, guacamole, tomatoes, cheese, lettuce and sour cream. Hubby had the roasted vegetable pasta and that was quite tasty too though it would be nice if the canned Roma tomatoes were broken up a bit.   The restrooms were a little gnarly but not bad. I would definitely go back there if I can't find anything else in the area.

gbGKaWOG8mnH0uvJVMSecQ.review_text: It has to be said. Well, we all know Max's now sucks. It was sold to a Gaelic businessman and years of recipes and hard work have been thrown under the bus, a long articulated MUNI one. Max's was known for Matzo Ball Soup. Well, this soup now has a horrible greasy flavor and solid dumplings ...so far from matzo ball soup that Pluto thanks MAX gratefully (that's my dog). Really, you have to taste this stuff once in a while if you are going to sell it.  Oh, if that was only the half of it. I would give MAX negative stars for the way the current owner has destroyed an institution! I have tried it many times in the last year, only to be disappointed again and again. Don't even get me started on the untrained staff that now work there. They don't even know how to take a phone order, much less wait on a table in MAX style.

eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg.review_text: II tried their Corned Beef Sandwich for the 1st time today since it's suppose to be their specialty.  I was NOT IMPRESSED AT ALL.   For $12, I got a few thin slices of dry corned beef on stale, old rye bread. The sandwich was so dry, that with every bite, I had to wash it down with Diet Coke. They didn't even give me horseradish with it!    WTF was I thinking coming here?!?!?!  To make matters worse, I thought I would be able to "grab and go" since I tried their online take-out order option. I really don't understand the purpose of this, as you still have to wait in line with other people placing/waiting for their orders. So, expect a 10-15 minute wait if you do this. A separate window should be created for "pick-up" orders only.   I never noticed this before, but why do they place their sides and condiments (e.g. potato salad, coleslaw, pickles, etc) in the open in their hallway?  As people walk-by, they can sneeze and cough into it. YUCK!  Anyhoo, while I was waiting to pick-up my order, one of the servers was carrying a plastic bag, and the tip of the bag was touching the potato salad. And, as she moved a long, it touched the other sides/condiments.  Who knows where that plastic bag has been!  I should have taken my lazy butt to Tommy's...

606AwWgDkRE9yo11qhf1zA.review_text: Wonderful piano player. Ok food. Horrible waiter named Monte who did not want to split the bill and rushed us through the meal. Sorry you had things to do, Monte, but we were paying for a decent meal....

kLDcF1QprLUcXC_QvRUEqg.review_text: Went there after the Giant's World Series Parade and we were lucky to be one of the first ones there before the crowd hit.   The service: They were attentive at the beginning when taking our orders, but we had to repeatedly ask for refills on water and even asking them, it took them forever to get back to us.  I understand crowds were getting bigger and the place was getting packed, but don't neglect those who are sitting down!   The food:  I had the Crab Cake sandwich.  Bland!  The Crab Cake itself tasted like it was some frozen patty and it was thin.  It just tasted greasy.  The kids had mac n cheese and the all beef hotdog.  My niece said the hotdog was "thin" and it was very much so.  My brother had a sandwich which seemed alright.  Their potato salad had a funny taste to it and I wasn't so sure if it's the relish or it just went bad.  Overall:  Meh, I can pass since the place can be pricey for diner food.

L06lGNdDqmXILqC3ND27Cg.review_text: I can't speak too generally for the epicurean experience that is Max's, but whenever I get the first inklings of a cold, I come a runnin' for their Matzoh Ball Soup.  Well, they say that there's no satisfied customer like the one who has a problem that is well addressed by the establishment...so it is here.  I went in today to salve my unhappy throat with a couple of quarts of MBS...unfortunately, they were out of the sturdy plastic quart containers and gave me four of the more flimsy styrofoam pint containers with paper-thin plastic tops.  By the time I got home, the upper containers cracked through the lower containers in the little stacks in the bag, leaving a nice puddle of soup in the bottom of the bag.  I called  the manager and told them what happened and they were very apologetic and offered replacement when I next came in.  More surprisingly (for a $4 item), they called me again later to apologize again and to assure me that they would take care of me.    THAT is the way it's supposed to happen.  Bravo, Max...Bravo.  --- FOLLOW UP on JAN 18th ---  Went back in to Max's for lunch with a friend and spoke with Mary, the manager who had called methe day before - again she was apologetic and said she'd take care of it.  At the end of our meal, with no need for a reminder, the waiter brought a quart of the soup to the table - even though all I'd lost was a pint.  They're keeping me as a customer, fo sho.

80wXjQalTwYgXEV2FZvsrQ.review_text: My mom and I ate here for the 1st time last week in the evening since we were visiting.  It was ok. The place is cool with the decor and the pianist.  We both got salads...they were indeed big and filling but I will say not really worth the price. I think 15-18 bucks is kind of silly for a salad even if its an entree...it better be one heck of a salad. Alas, they were good but not memorable.  I got the chicken & cabbage salad with hoisin dressing which was good but where was the cilantro?  Again, just not worth the price but it did feed me so I guess that's a plus. The service was efficient but not real friendly.  I think the place's vibe deserves personality from their staff.

5Z-MIkbpuoaiPSc1ZPboug.review_text: This is an upfront and honest kind of place.  The food is great, portions are hearty, and you'll probably want to come back another time when you have room for dessert. The bathroom situation is a bit of a nightmare; not nearly enough stalls for the size of restaurant, but otherwise the service is excellent and the dining area is welcoming.  It's very nicely decorated at the holidays if you are looking for somewhere festive.  Well located for AMC Van Ness.

J88MRsq3n8T1mYNgem0Jew.review_text: Max's is one of my favorite places to eat in the city. I almost always get the grilled cheese sandwich and fries. Breaking from the simple origins of the grilled cheese, Max's allows you to combine some fairly exotic (or at the very least, "non-traditional") cheeses for a fairly unique take on an ultra simple dish. Their fries are probably my favorite french fries in the world, and good God do they give you a lot of them.  Bottom line - when you come to Max's, expect to stuff yourself silly.  Four stars - only because I greatly prefer their Union Square location.

suuIf6JWTZFjSu55k7zTBA.review_text: Walking into Max's I felt dwarfed by the gynormous cakes and heart stopping comfort food. This is the place where you come for a BIG eat. Located a stone's throw from City Hall, the ballet, symphony and movie theater (at Opera Plaza), it's a great place to stop in for a bite or a snack. For this visit, I enjoyed the Roasted Veggie Wrap ~ a spinach tortilla wrap with caramelized onions, roasted peppers, portobello mushrooms, avocado, feta cheese, hummus, and fresh spinach. It comes with a tasty side salad of fresh corn, arugula, red onions, and tomatoes, lightly dressed. If you come by later in the evening, they have a tendency to run out of certain items. We opted for the apple pie and chuckled as a flyer saucer of a pie landed on our table. I'd forgotten that Max's does it BIG. It was a tad dry, heavy on the crust and encrusted with sugar. The bright side is that I didn't chow it all down, so I've another meal for tomorrow. The service is friendly. They have a pianist depending on the time of day and sometimes the servers will sing a jaunty tune. A treat for the the ears and for the belly. PS: If you want to plan ahead, here's their sample menu: maxsattheopera.com/id1.h…

gDnCUfo0IT_hDl85Vr-h5Q.review_text: We went here to eat before going to the symphony on Saturday night. My Mom and Dad both had the prime rib special which was average.   One thing at Max's is that you can actually get a baked potato!  In San Francisco? Unheard of!  The sour dough rolls are good, but a little tough on the outside. The pianist is a very nice, classy touch!

fdVCBVz4VWLo2bMbPsco9Q.review_text:
OK, so I haven't eaten at this location yet, but I have eaten at the one in the Stanford mall, and the diner that used to be at 3rd and folsom a lot.
  BEST REUBEN IN THE CITY hands down.  I have not had better.  (If anyone knows better, PLEASE LET ME KNOW!!!).  Corned beef is good, but Pastrami is better.
  If they have the same menu as the one in PA, they have those aged steaks, which are pretty good too.  Service has always been good, esp at the opera cafe, where they sing.
  If I remember right, they also have a "fi' dolla shake" that was damn good.  It better be, right?

ZpCoPnVGGsY3-myj-9m7Pg.review_text: I have been here a couple of times and always had a good time. I could be biased since they always sing the songs i like. The size of their portions is crazy and it may not be the best, but it is still good. If on the desserts you need two hands to hold it up, congrats, you have impressed me.   The idea of having your servers being the entertainers is inventive...and cheap, the idea seems like  a sleazy jazz bar business model, but it works well here. I personally think this restaurant is a good place to eat and be entertained if you are having a brain fart on what to do that night.

zj3FG24HjTjmf8k60EUr4Q.review_text: Very lovely place for dinner, while still keeping a comfortably casual feeling. The food is good, as is the service. They have live piano music, and the windows opening out onto South Van Ness make it great for the start or close of an evening out. Max's is a place that reminds me why I love living in San Francisco. It's nice, even fancy, but without pretension. Cap it off with a night-time walk around the lit up City Hall or maybe walking down to Smuggler's Cove for a drink, and you'll have a fine evening.

c4K55UM0pZvreFSSQUjWxQ.review_text: We went here before the opera on Sunday noon. Had a very nice table in the bar area. Max's has influences of a Kosher Deli with lots of great sandwiches. I had the Russian cabbage soup which was excellent. Then a Greek salad--I've had better, but it wasn't bad. Service was delightful, as was the atmosphere. I've eaten here once before on pride day. We had a good size party and we were no longer sober. Had a great meal and the great wait staff but us with our boisterous style.  One interesting note: the restaurant has to provide any staff working 10h or more some type of health insurance or subsidy. For that they add a 5+% surcharge to your tab. I don't mind. I think everyone should have healthcare.  (I'll be losing mine at the end of the month because of my gender. But that's another story.)

kMydoq5VVGtTIY1tpT-tKw.review_text: I hosted a farewell cocktail party for my boss here and the space was perfect for the crowd (100ish people). The staff/management where all great and very attentive and accommodating. The food (finger noshes) were all very good and they provided more than enough. For the price, it was a steal! I highly recommend Max's for group get togethers and will definitely go back for lunch or dinner.

MM9oxTXKL6utP1Zq9Eno6g.review_text: Good spot to drop in after watching the ballet since it is walking distance. You have to be quick because everyone else has the same idea and there is a long wait ;) Ordered a grilled salmon sandwich and lemonade. Portions are huge.

k_seSrhHW-vjB-W3Vh-XEw.review_text: *sigh* it wasn't horrible, just that...  well, if I hadn't had Reubens recently at Lunch Geek (sadly only an occasional kitchen experiment), Saul's, and The Kitchen Table (okay that last is technically not a Reuben as that is a non-dairy restaurant, but still)  max's takes it for size, and the dressing and bread were good, as was the side of cole slaw, but the corned beef was mediocre  I debated whether to make this a two or three star review, but ultimately I have to give it a two as the meat is the main point of a Reuben  and now that I know what good corned beef tastes like (from the three other places), I can't go back

ra3OzaxpILytSjHRRKoT8g.review_text: Split a Reuben four ways, and maybe you won't feel like you committed the sin of gluttony eating here.  They used to do half a BLT and a cup of soup (matzo ball of course), but for some reason, that's not an option anymore.  That was my choice, and I could maintain some sense of virtue about the whole experience.  And even enjoy it.  How often does one get a good BLT these days?  Never.  Now, the food just seems monstrously excessive, and fine, but not great.  Add to that the vaguely chain experience, and it's really not on my list, except when I come with the occasional group lunch.  I'd rather go to Morty's any day (or night).

OK5B_PHxTDlLfhmIV2MxPw.review_text: It's a restaurant by the opera house... How cool could it possibly be???  At dinner time we found a place to park, right across the street on Van Ness. Could happen. Right before me n wifey walk in, some bum proclaims how awesome we look, and asks "Are we locals?"  Too bad I didn't have any spare change.  It's a nice place, nice bar, even live piano lounge music. Good, friendly service. Waiters are a lil tongue in cheek (at least).  Great sandwiches. It's the sh!t.  The prices aren't bad. I'd go again.

dvmz7wDSGnNm-ZkTna1yzw.review_text: Great for large parties.  The singing is good most of the time, but it does get a bit loud for a great conversation.  The food choices are great which means that there is something for everyone.  Most dishes have super large portions, but there are always things available in a smaller size.  Solid wine selection.  The matzo ball soup is  one of the second best in the city.

486c4Pznd00sbs2wh7eNyg.review_text: OK, the cheesecakes are pretty good, but my question to this business is: do you want business at all? Why don't you keep your doors open for your listed business hours? What's the point of business hours if you close early? I was there at 9:45pm the other night, a full 15 minutes before the supposed closing time. The place was quite full otherwise. Locked. What's up with that?

McPU8udr9OLqYKh8wFQpGw.review_text: Max's is a little pricey for what is essentially a diner experience. The singing is nice, and my Manhattan was actually pretty good, as was the food. But the $ for it was a little ridiculous. I didn't even have to pay, as it was a going away party, but honestly I felt guilty seeing how much everyone else had to pay. The food was a bit greasy, the service was pretty good, I'm just not sure the price was worth what you got.

k6TAJ5zNSP7ID0bVHr89Zg.review_text: Consistently good, very reasonably priced, and the service is just right.  Great location to meet with business partners and those that you need to catch-up with minus the fan fare.

RiPHX-gOa1R4qKZJ0fBSaw.review_text: Today I decided to give myself a birthday treat. Lunch at Max's is always the same, tasty, enjoyable, no unpleasant surprises.  Prices are reasonable, certainly in line with the food quality.  The last time there my husband and I, along with two friends were celebrating our wedding vows, taken the hour before at City Hall.  I always like their brew-at-the-table pot of iced tea.  When I do it myself the strength is perfect, the lemon and sweetness just right.  Instead of bread they serve, when requested, two warm rolls, one sourdough, one raisin.  Again, excellent.  Today I had the Chicken Caesar Wrap with Arugula Salad.  Their Caesar dressing may not be totally authentic (but whose is, nowadays), however I really like it. I especially enjoy the salads, crab cake appetizer and vegetable stuffed baked potato. The meal portions are just short of huge.  Every time I eat there I promise myself one of their yummy and huge desserts. Today, as always, I'm too full after my main course and can't even look at the dessert menu.  A few times I've gone there with friends just for dessert and have never been disappointed.  I do have one small complaint.  For some reason I've never been able to figure out the wait person almost always chooses to ask me how my meal is when my mouth is full and I can only nod my appreciation.  It's a small price to pay for an otherwise pleasurable dining experience.  I highly recommend Max's.

sN6XqrVCINH-_fBbLiPleg.review_text: I haven't been this disappointed in a meal in a very long time. This restaurant would be right at home in rural Pennsylvania if the prices were cheaper. Yuck.  I had the luis salad. Nothing about it was redeemable. The shrimp was like the cheapest you could find, brocoli reminded me of the snacks in elementary school, lettuce wasn't crisp. Really just gross for 18 dollars!? The soup of the day is $8 and also very basic, diner style stuff. You're going to pay the same prices at Max's as you would at a very nice restaurant, like 03 down the street, but get Mel's quality food. The menu is huge (always a red flag), not as huge as cheesecake factory - which by the way is much better, if that says anything. The piano player was not very good either - very average show-tunes on a blown out speaker.  You know, I hate to disparage my fellow yelpers ,but if you look at the profiles of the folks giving this place 4 stars, you'll see they mostly review diners and places like home depot. This place is just sad.

dCxov70AJSrCAKi6FPyn5g.review_text: Yes, this place is a bit overpriced. But hey, you're eating at a place next to two or three auditoriums that have venues with hungry people. Sometimes its good to experience an overpriced place to understand why it's overpriced, then decide if its worth it or not.  I went there after watching a piano recital; place was conveninet and I didn't have to feel cheap by walking to the burger king. Had their ground sirloin steak entree; it's pretty good. Didn't knew it came with baked potatoes AND creamed spinach, along with onion fries. At $17, yes it is a lot. but then again the next time i had a craving for Max's opera, I opted for San Tung and ended up foring $20 for my meal of chicken wings and black bean noodles.   Lesson? you may think its overpriced until you go to another joint and end up paying the same amount. Know what to order and you'll be fine. also, buy their creamed horseradish. or not. haha i just found it at bevmo for $2.50; this place charged $4.50, but it seemed more than 12oz

uXJcEHOQMjxweEKmfPla4w.review_text: I ordered crab cakes with warm slaw and mushrooms. My date ordered chicken piccata. We shared a beet salad, which was swimming in oil and so salty I gave up on it. If my crab cakes ever saw a crab, it was because one walked by the kitchen. They were mealy and tasteless, so I left two out of three on the plate. Like the beet salad, the warm slaw was drenched in oil. I had to ask for the mushrooms because they were omitted. When they arrived it was obvious they were straight from a can. Terrible. My date liked his chicken piccata, so that's why I gave it two stars. If I based this on my meal alone, they'd get no stars at all. The service was attentive and prompt, and the coffee afterwards was first-rate. This meal was an expensive disaster. We're not coming back.

ZCRu62ymZW8ibZkY6qZh-Q.review_text: Max's is way overpriced (what is the bagel with lox, $9? $13? who are they kidding) with only decent food. The reuben bites were on the low side of decent.  I didn't care for the music either.  Don't go here if you want a cheap, quick snack.

dAQ4E8_BX5W63fS5IR2rhw.review_text: Two stars because it used to be a great place and I hope it becomes a great place again but, it has gone way, way, way downhill since we started eating here fifteen years ago!   I have good memories of this place. My favorite memory is of taking my son to Max's when he was a baby, which we did regularly. There was this one GREAT waitress who used to take time out to walk him around the restaurant so he'd stop crying and I could eat!!! The waitress moved to LA and we wished her well-- I hope she reads this--we are thinking about you and still wishing you well.   This restaurant used have a heart, the type of heart that could warm you up on a cold rainy San Francisco evening. Like, come on in, sit for awhile, enjoy the music, the staff, and have a Corned Beef Sandwich or a bowl of Chicken Soup while you are here.  The food was never more than competently prepared but the restaurant used to really have soul. I  compare the Old Max's to a good Northeast Diner experience: Friendly personality, competent food, large portions and an over-sized menu (What happened, Max? Your menu shrunk! Your old, over-sized menu was part of the fun of dining with you).  Max's soul is gone. I read in other reviews that it was sold or under new management but, I really don't know.  We just had some of the worst customer service I have experienced in San Francisco,  a city known for its restaurants. We were given a wait buzzer to a half empty restaurant--what other restaurant in the city gives out buzzers when it is half empty? When we asked to be seated on the quieter side of the restaurant, the hostess, seemed to punish us by giving us heavy sighs and saying, "You will have to wait longer then (even though there were clearly five or six empty tables on the side we wanted)".  People were sat before us on the side we wanted--I saw it. So, I complained to the manager. We were then, rushed to a table on the more crowded, noisy side (piano side)--the side we did not want! It felt like spite, even if it wasn't done out of spite, it did not matter. So....we left...  Phffftt....unfriendly, there was a sense that Max's could care less. And, there was a very strong sense of them treating us like we were problem guests (Hostess, threw her hands up and exclaimed, "What did I do wrong?" Answer: Well, you treated us like we were asking too much because we wanted to be placed on the quieter side and we were going to be punished for asking that question).  HOT TIP FOR OUT OF TOWNERS COMING INTO SF FOR THE OPERA OR SYMPHONY:  There are tons of great restaurants in Hayes Valley neighborhood, and many are close to the Civic Center. We ended up leaving Max's Opera Cafe and going to Chez Maman on Gough St. At first, I thought we were really striking out on restaurants for the evening because I had to ask for a waiter to come to the table after waiting for a very long time. BUT, boy oh boy, THIS RESTAURANT understands customer service so much better than MAX's!!!!! Apologies happened from both the hostess and server! They were honest that  no server was assigned to us (Sounded like it was the bubbly, friendly hostess's fault--and, she clearly felt awful about it--and given her level of empathy, we forgave her and tipped to server well--accidents do happen--and, thank you Chez Maman for either properly training your hostess or just plainly hiring well). They made it up to us! We were told that our food was going to be rushed since we were sitting for so long. And, the restaurant offered to comp us for something we did not want--so, we did not take the comp!  Max's Opera Cafe clearly has issues. I hope they get their act together but--sigh, I am not holding my breath. It has been a slow downhill change in customer service for at least a year or so. The waiters are not as friendly as they used to be. Last time, drinks were forgotten, etc....

4lhXgCLfXZCANN6_iqFn2A.review_text: Watch out for overcharges on your drinks.  Especially watch out for the bartender, Kristie.

Fr_rLfBcfvVVXkLTanrkvA.review_text: It saddens me that I've eaten lunch here so many times, but it is super convenient to the courthouse.  The food is average and overpriced, and the service is hit or miss.  Nothing here really stands out, but my standby is the soup-salad combo with the matzo ball soup and the caesar salad.  The soup sometimes has a ton of chicken and is sometimes pretty sparse.  The matzo ball is average in texture and flavor.  The salad isn't swimming in dressing, which is nice.  Other dishes that are decent but unexciting include the turkey dinner, and the pastrami and eggs.  The latkes have a bit of an odd texture and weren't flavorful enough for me.  Make sure to ask for extra apple sauce if you order them.

tIRh_AmxJhUgzoHUBMPnlA.review_text: Service we got was excellent.  Food portion was big but a bit on a pricey side.  I ordered a tuna with asparagus & artichokes, it was ok.  One thing I love though is the Chocolate Sundae.

ONl2QlK_0uOu7g1xaxRvPw.review_text: Their pastrami sandwiches are as good as they come -- comparable to the best of New York. Lots of mustard options, too -- several available at the table.   And add to that the excellent singing and piano playing -- a perfect prelude or denouement to an evening at the symphony, opera, ballet, or Music Conservatory performance.

OdDALgWgxB1gqVmfjVRoxw.review_text: This place was just alright. Nothing special or out of the ordinary. The piano Player and the waitress's that sing were nice. I split the turkey sandwich and a salad with my mom. I have had better for cheaper. I don't know if the waitress was having a bad day or what, but she wasn't very friendly. The pepper grinder at our table wasn't working and when I told her she seemed annoyed. Hey, it's not my fault you have pepper grinders that malfunctioned. Sorry Max's, but next trip to S.F. I'll be skipping you!

aBfT6rp0tfhEyc7fWeuYJA.review_text: Blech.   I had a friend who worked here and that place is scary.  The portions are plentiful and the hot fudge flows, but overall an unpleasant atmosphere and poor service make visits to Max's few and far between.

-S2Hq66wA5a3ZgQwDSFQ3w.review_text: Wow...talk about H U G E portions.  Their food was alright but the dessert was my favorite.  My boyfriend and I shared the banana split which looked like it was made for at least 5 people...but so yummy...wish I would have ate a little less dinner because we couldn't finish the dessert!  The singing waiters is also a plus...a little entertainment while you eat...although when we went our waiter seemed more occupied with his singing session than bringing us our food.

wE_BzyibHCASTjEpMVRq-g.review_text: We came here for lunch before heading over to Davies for a show.  I had allocated two hours for lunch, so I figured we should be fine timewise.  But once we got to the front of the line, people with reservations kept jumping to the front of the line ahead of us.  I was getting ready to physically block them from cutting in.    They asked us if we had a reservation, we didn't.  Then they asked us if we minded eating at the bar, we didn't.  I ordered the lamb burger.  I asked for it well done, it arrived medium to medium rare.  The lamb burger was excellent anyway.  I tried it with some of the sauce on the side, but it tasted better naked.  I really felt sorry for our server/bartender.  One person to handle 10 people eating at the bar simultaneously?  She never checked on us to see how our food was, but did eventually refill our water glasses.  She looked frazzled, and I couldn't blame her.    Prices are a little on the high side, but the huge portion size makes up for that!

qcftelJRgcTAA8C8wkfvWQ.review_text: I went to Max's for dinner before the Symphony on Saturday night with three other people. We all had great meals and excellent service. If anything, the portions are a bit too much - which is wonderful... and the food was great!

sSW5sb1Y9FM_D9cXAfPnUQ.review_text: Max's used to be fun.  Now it's more like a cranky old man.  An expensive, cranky old man.    There's not anything special.    Servings are huge, but not the kind where you think, "Ok this is so delicious, and I have enough for lunch tomorrow."  It's "Do I want to even bother taking this stuff home?  Will I ever eat it, or will I just end up tossing it in a week?"  (I ask for take-out, then leave it outside on the bench for one of the many street folk who always seem hungry.)   I wish that Gordon Ramsay would give Max's a makeover.

ZUk37WJbVRJJa2s_sX3D_g.review_text: The portions are huge especially sandwiches.  I ordered 2 appetizers: chicken wings and stuffed baked giant mushrooms.  Chicken wings are spicy and tasty, yet a bit too salty for my taste.  Mushrooms are smaller than I thought.   The focaccia bread that comes with the mushroom are just bland even with the tomato sauce.   My friends had sandwiches, and the portions were GIGANTINO.  The salmon dish was quite small and a bit dry.

2bYx8Bdf14SOU3hxydWwrQ.review_text: i suggest the crabcake sandwich- its flaky and crispy a well made crabcake which most places cant seem to do right. not only is it gynormous but it also comes with fries and cole slaw, everything here is big. i especially appreciate the staff with really courteous and friendly servers and hosts/hostesses. just try to avoid after nutcrakcer and ballet hours around 4:30-5pm when it gets pretty busy with often times a wait.

pp39KlvUD5EedRqDF8WotQ.review_text: Unfortunate that they've got a great location.  The food is mediocre at best, but it's the bad management that's most amazing.  Waiters joking with each other while tables needed busing. 2Bn3JIt3eB9vx591KPhQUw.review_text: Arrrrgh!! This place used to be decent at best and now it is even worse. I will never go back!! normally I write really detailed yelper feedback but all I can say is "STAY AWAY!!"

Z95FWe3KNicCF0QWSVUfrA.review_text: A good place for dessert and a drink.  The weekends feature live music to enjoy in this newly remodeled bar area.  I had a great late harvest zin an dthe desserts were great.

nefq9skjrf1FLHd0esB1TA.review_text: Great Reuben sandwich!  Good location for pre-ballet/opera/symphony dinner.

DKmUukETiMVidu548TE-zw.review_text: In so many ways, Max's is not my cup of tea.  The Broadway singing, the mediocre dessert compensated by giving you an enormous portion of mediocre dessert.    However, this is the only place open late enough when my friends and I need a non-dinner place to discuss the movies we just saw at the Opera Plaza movie theatre.   And I have had many fond memories, with my legs stretched out on the comfortable booth seat,  eating dessert I don't like, pretend we are a bunch of old farts in a Manhattan all-night diner a la Woody Allen, and feeling my brain cells finally reviving just little bit since college days by a nice, stimulating intellectual conversations on the latest worthwhile film.    Oh, Max's is good to me.

Zia61WCddJBqIc_Z5-7coA.review_text: I used to really like coming here as it was one of the first places me and my husband ever went to when we started dating. When we arrived on a Sunday night after dinner for dessert the restaurant was pretty empty. My nieces wanted dessert so we chose this place for their strawberry shortcake. The orders were $10 a slice. It was good but worth $10, I'm not so sure. The waitress started singing and there was one other big party seated in the dining room. Not the best service but good cake. They used to have lots of cakes displayed in their case but not so much anymore.

af3BXGK9-cqBK6vyRPDFrg.review_text: Drinks after the opera, Sunday brunch, or gigantic sandwiches.  Nothing special for food but the waiter/singers make it enjoyable.. FYI the mini sandwiches are large enough for almost anyone.

SwczYdPhx5w2uhXSeIALLQ.review_text: This place just isn't what it used to be. Unless you're stopping in for a huge slice of cake it just isn't worth it anymore.

Cw4hN4lX9gu7fDfsC7rilA.review_text: Their "Grandma's Roast Chicken" is fantastic and so are the Latkes.  We order in usually from Waiters on Wheels but have been to the restaurant a couple of times.  The desserts are also excellent!

AtXaPcXyUKkII6BYJP4_kQ.review_text: Yay for dinners consisting of Bistro Salad (no bacon) and brownie sundae.    Not a lot of choice for vegetarians.

AeMCsLNA5dAsbmP1Cf_Zrw.review_text: The service is great but I can only give three stars mainly because of two reasons. First, unappetizing drinks. My brother's Arnold Palmer tasted like Lipton iced tea loaded with pure lemon juice and my Bloody Mary was way too peppery and bitter. Secondly, cold food. I think they wait until all dishes are ready before serving. We're party of eight and it should take more than five minutes. My brother chopped steak dinner already gone cold when it arrived and you know how medium rare would taste when it's cold; soggy and watery. Monday's special; a little too salty chicken quesadilla served with sour cream, salsa and cacuamole altogether in a small container, and delish Caesar salad.

1DzehxDkhtKZJVXRI3ltOA.review_text:

A1s0L-5K8x1LPu3Iodt0Xw.review_text: I have not eaten in, I have only had their cakes and eclair's. They are to die for!!! Huge and delicious!!

puYmrcccLvW3EnKDFNqSmw.review_text: We had lunch at Max because it was on the way to the Theater - Their location is great but food and staff not so good (it seemed they do not want to work). The food was ok but the service was slow. The couple on the next table got the wrong drink and had to return it. The Host is in the middle of the floor - never seen that before - no one by the door to welcome you.

uZdFsE_aHbFBChgN6Xa8tw.review_text: Service was great and this place fills up fast!  Make reservations or get there before noon.  I had the Thursday special - turkey, gravy and cranberry sandwich.  It was on non-toasted white bread and had no taste.  The turkey was dry but the gravy and cranberry were good.  I'd probably order something else.  The 4 stars is for the service.

4tA5Bky_dq71PouStf7ZFA.review_text: My friend had his birthday party here. The manager agreed to charge only two corkage fees for however many bottles of wine we'd bring (and we brought several cases for this large party). When our large party showed up, the staff had heard nothing of the deal, and the manger, on the phone, reneged. Unbelievably, they argued with us for 45 minutes as we waited to start our party, kind of spoiling it for us.   The food was good, nothing to rave about, and the wait staff was pretty good. But, the management really burned us. I'll avoid this place!

0zP5l85BSYGBm0HRgRZa-w.review_text: I guess if you want meat, potatoes and dessert, this place would satisfy. But, I was looking for something healthier. I got the beet salad. Big mistake, the nice colorful beets are on top of a mound of coleslaw with mayo- gross. My friend got the grilled cheese sandwich and fries plate. I can attest that the fries are good - meaty with a nice, not too salty seasoning. Plates are large and would fill a big appetite. I do have to give a large thumbs up for the big stuffed mushroom appetizer- I would go back just for that. So, I would say that your experience definitely would depend upon what you order. A comment to the waiter, you never know who will be providing the tip, so give equal attention to all parties.

AJ3HgRkVP4NzK-wVNKQzew.review_text: Ate here while in the city for work.  Had a rueben.  Tons of food so that helps to justify the price (but, hey, it's SF).  Our waiter was very nice and attentive (we had a group of 5).  Only real complaint was that we were in early while it wasn't too busy but it still took us over 1 hour to order, eat and pay the bill.

hixDahqRvt3V2rKyLAuhog.review_text: Who can eat here on their lunch hour when you have to burn over ten minutes just waiting to order in an empty restaurant? Meanwhile three or four employees are just standing around talking to each other while I search on my phone to find another place to eat.  Then my waitress appears for the first time when I hear her and the hostess get into a subdued but clear verbal altercation.    As always the food here is 5 stars.   Food came quick and I loved it.  Check took forever.  Service is two stars.  I recommend take out over staying to eat if you're on your lunch hour.

G1aAbnM1QAaKsoKWvCRRsg.review_text: Good portions, food tastes as it should.  Solid, no frills thrills.  --No idea what the inside of the restaurant is like, however- good luck.

ixxfMzn3-vBRgG10ofwLgw.review_text: 2 stars for the convenience. It would've been 1, but the OTT singing from the servers boosted it up to 2. It was LOL worthy and entertaining.  I got a salad here...and the lettuce is what would've made this a 1 star review. Lettuce was old - like slimy and starting to turn colors. I know from experience that when that happens, the lettuce has been sitting for at least 5 days. Either that or their supplier doesn't give them the freshest of produce. Either way, as I was eating through my second salad (first one I sent back) that was fractionally better than the first, I had a perfect view of McDonald's and Chevy's. I should've gone to either of those instead of paying $18 for a chicken caesar salad.  Why do they have to douse everything liberally with celery salt?!

C5aLaESIlrN6ThOhaGZ72Q.review_text: My wife and I occasionally dine at Max's because it's very convenient to Symphony Hall. Previous visits have been pretty good, but last night was a strikeout.  After a 30-minute wait (they said it would be 20-30), we were seated. Water and bread came out within a few minutes. So far, so good. That would be the last time we would be offered either.  After 45 minutes, our sirloins arrived. We both had ordered medium rare; both were well done. We called over our super busy waitress and she took them back to the kitchen. About 30 minutes later, they came back out. Mine was medium rare; my wife's was mooing it was so bloody.  If you can't get a medium rare steak from a restaurant after two tries, it fails in my book. My wife ate a few bites, but we had to get to the symphony so didn't send it back a second time. She took a doggy bag and we fed it to our dog when we got home.  The accompaniments were just OK...creamed spinach and a baked potato. Again, a hard dinner to screw up, but that they did.  Not sure if we'll be back. Will probably look for a new option near the symphony.

hjxST6rVRUODe-pEldi98A.review_text: Okay so Max's has great food I can admit that but the service is kinda terrible. I go there to get desert every time I have a dance recital. The deserts are crazy good and so is the chicken matzo ball soup. The service is the worst part. Once my sister left her video camera there and we hadn't relized it until we were at home. We called and they kept putting us on hold. The food takes like thirty minutes to get to you. Once we asked for a container and they totally forgot so we had to go to the counter. They also forget every thing and you have to ask at least three times.                                               -Nikki

65Q0wWN6G6wJfG6NfiiPvg.review_text: When we're in the city on a budget, we come here.  We usually split the pot pie and a drink or two.  It's huge and yummy and we can leave with full bellies and some extra cash for drinking later.  Its cozy and service is usually pretty good.  Maybe next time we'll try one of the desserts on display when you walk in.

4nZlMrDw-mrvmfEVT-cQrw.review_text: everyone that works in the area goes here.  you have to get there about 15 minutes before noon if you want to get a decent seat.  service was good, the sandwich i got was huge, but it was pricey.  you gotta try the reuben & the corned beef sandwhich...lots of meat!   i love the different types of bread they serve while you're waiting for your food.  they're open for breakfast and people flock to max's in the morning because you can smell the bacon a block away

fHuv6rbv5PxF07tNCCtfPQ.review_text: these people are racists!!!  i know that's a serious allegation to make, but i was just as shocked that in this day and age, especially in SF no less, this would happen.  it was pretty late at night and max's was close by.  BF and i walked up to the door at the same time as this other couple.  i won't elaborate, but they were the typical max's customers (you get the idea.  but it's NOT that we looked like vagrants or had boorish manners.)  BF opened the door for them, so they were a few paces ahead of us.  the hostess seated them.  then when she came back, she told us they were closed.  i started to sputter and say how come those people who pretty much arrived at the same time as us got seated?  she spat as us 'well, the kitchen has to close some time you know.'  rather than make a scene, we went to chevy's instead, where I spent the night fuming and envisioning bricks hurled through their window.  and then flames coming out.  to this day, that was one of my biggest regrets in life, behaving like a model minority.  if i could go back in time i would've hit them with a fat lawsuit for discrimination.  or at the very least make an ugly scene.  then, this other time way back (before that incident obviously), i went to max's for my birthday.  had a huge group with me.  i don't know if it was because once again, we didn't look like the typical max's customers, but the waitress served us almost grudgingly.  i wondered, did she think we were going to be stingy asian college student tippers?  but then again, how could she possibly expect a good tip with that shoddy a service?   so yes, this place SUCKS.  even if they should happen to have the finest food in the universe, they still SUCK.

bWTIMv6FKnkOEfxw7yR5jw.review_text: Oh snap!!  Have you tried the chicken wings here????  Good lord they are tasty....

4wOcvMLtU6a9Lslggq74Vg.review_text: I came here with a couple of friends, one being Mr. Billy S, and had high expectations. After quickly being seated, it took a bit to get a waiter to help us- he was playing the piano and singing. The food was decent, but definitely not worth the price. Another huge problem is the parking. gjhzKWsqCIrpEd9pevbKZw.review_text: The Caesar salad with house-made dressing and parmigiano-reggiano cheese is delicious! Matzo ball soup was also good. I haven't eaten in at this location but have been pleased with take-out.

m5nb4WNYldQpWd3ZEr05BQ.review_text: I've had consistently good food at all of the Max's restaurants, which has me wondering if everything comes prepackaged. Obviously, it does not, but they must have some expert chefs to make it taste right every time.  I miss the Opera part of Max's, but enjoy it nonetheless. Just split a slice of cake and be done with it.

99NcsApGTVHpDClWSW8_iQ.review_text: Split the Beet Salad and Crab Cake Sandwich, which was a delightful combo. Crab Cake Sandwich bun over powered the cake with all its carbohydrate. Pink lemonade is served in tall double pint glass which I found very nice and in comparison to my companion's tiny coffee - was a jolly pink giant lemonade! Will stop in to grab a chocolate covered macaroon next time I'm about the square. I recommend you do the same!

WqTHIvwkGGsfyECH1tgcmQ.review_text: My husband and I always go to Max's Opera Cafe before the Symphony on Friday nights. It's consistently good, the service is friendly and attentive, and the extensive menu covers everything from salads to sandwiches to entrees of beef, chicken, fresh fish, and vegetarian choices. Although it's not a negative, the servings are more than ample, so two people can share a salad or entree if a lighter meal is in order.

Fz3y-d7Ru7wMRnPuwG-OLA.review_text: My friend and i went here before a show at the Grandballroomatoriumaria for a small quick bite. Ill repeat that. A small. Quick. Bite. For one, nothing on the menu feeds less than 23 people. The portions are ginormous. Mid-Westerners named Steve Zerbsky, listen up...this is the place you bring your wife Linda on you vacation away from Downer's Grove, Illinois. I order some nachos, and got a festive mutlicolored volcano that took two waiters to EZ Lift over. My friend got a salmon burger that was so big, youd think they lopped the head and tail off and slapped it on a loaf of Franch (not French, it is pronounced Fronche) bread. Oh, and like 2.64 pounds of potatoes were harmed in the making of the fries. I will return to conquer the 'chos. I will return to hear our server croon, and i will return to see what the hell that Reuben is all about.

DQxyV5vPnh_H7I9ycalVVA.review_text: the food was sub par for san francisco.  had a Caesar salad, and steak, med rare.  salad was fine.  steak was rare-raw, no flavor to it... first time I have asked for steak sauce at a restaurant in my adult life.  the dinner rolls were more like breakfast rolls, too sweet with a touch of cinnamon.

Ll_jDY55b3U8QdGu4As-2A.review_text: Almost decent diner food, what more can I say? The strawberry lemonade with raspberry flavor was damn good. I had some linguine that was so-so. My friend had a crab sandwich that was not good.   Almost funny signs.  I will almost go there again.

mxWmDpr3lR1VV46QmNGtTQ.review_text: The complimentary bread was the best thing here. Server was an odd character. Too sarcastic.

TNo1aPj4p9mXkHBR0uHfEg.review_text: This seems like such a let down after having gone to a performance.  But I had uncomfortable shoes on and we were starving after a three hour long opera.  The portions are truly Midwestern.  Everything was very fatty, it seemed just for the sake of being fatty and not to enhance the taste.  My beet salad was drenched with a thick dressing and had the biggest lumps of feta cheese I have even seen.  Tasted ok, but could have been so much better if they had tossed it in a nice light vinaigrette.  I had to bring about 2/3 of the thing home it was so big. I had a bite (a big bite) of the bacon cheese burger too.  The Bacon was very weird, it was hard and crunchy, reminded me of dog treats. And I would like to see the potatoes that the fries were cut from...those fuckers must be the size of pumpkins!  Do they use GM potatoes?  How big do potatoes get?  I think there was a French fry that was about the length of my arm! The prices are average, maybe a bit high but then you get a bucket, no a trough, of food with each order, so if you are a tourist from middle America, or just a local glutton, this is the place for you!

b1TLsiRhQdfbbXahqFkVtg.review_text: Over rated.  The sandwiches are often dry and the service is marginal...  In fact everything here is marginal.  Almost to the extreme.

BQ9WdOuWLKb1TYV97p_Fcg.review_text: I've had their food twice now, still deserves only one star.   The first time I ordered, it was a veggie 'burger'.  Ummm I was better off eating red meat. It was disgustingly greasy and the ciabatta bread for a burger? that was uncalled for! that was hard to swallow.......no really it was hard to chew and swallow. I like Ciabatta bread, but it was simply too much bread, to hard, too doughy, and hard to hold while eating. Everything was sliding out, I felt like a 3 year old eating a massive size burger mess and all.  I'll all for BIG stuff and large servings, but this just didn't taste good or go well. Who would have thought ordering a burger would come on ciabatta bread; that was upsetting.   Today, I'm suffering from stomach cramps and I have the trash can next to me. I'm seriously considering going home sick.   I'm sure it was a complete misunderstanding, I was given enough oil to keep a high volume KFC in business for 2 days.   I ordered a veggie sandwich this time and again it came in another ciabatta (this one was specified in the menu but I overlooked it), and wtf why another ciabbatta?! ugh, not happy but I still hate my food.   Every bite I took, had an ocean of oil gush into my mouth. I dismissed it, and said it was probably the fried onion onion strings in it. Then another gush of oil, I opened my sandwich up and noticed there was cheese, ok another reason for it to be oily...... so much for trying to stay away from fatty foods like red meat.  I'm beginning to get a little grossed out so I open my sandwich up again and start dissecting it. I find Spinach drenched in you guessed it oil, the ciabatta is falling apart because its a complete mush drenched in oil. Artichoke hearts bathed in oil, sauteed onions floating in oil, I couldn't take another bite. My gag reflex had had enough and it wasn't going to warn me anymore. I gave up after realizing I had to wipe my face and chin after every bite. Warm oil dripping down your chin looks cute!   Funny/ disgusting part:  remember those HOT summer days as a kid eating watermelon and the juice would drip down your arms to your elbow? yeah picture warm OIL dripping down to your elbows from this disgusting oil drenched ciabatta.   french fries are large steak fries.........they're forgettable.

Vdy219QdKTKmzTSy12FVnw.review_text: When I was contemplating moving to San Francisco (after grad school), and made many 12 hour flights (lay overs, you know) from New England, I always visited Max's, just for their smoked salmon sandwich.    You need only to eat once the entire day after such an amazingly huge sandwich.   It has or shall I say HAD, all of the major food groups; protein from the eggs and salmon, veggies from the largely cut tomatoes, red onions and whole olives, grains of course from the onion bagel, dairy from the wedges of swiss and muenster cheeses, and fruit from the garnishes of orange slices.    Perfection, no worries Mom, I have a "balanced" diet.    So, I move to San Francisco, and on my 2nd day here, I jump on the bus and head to Max's.  I graciously wait, and wait and get to the counter to order, and am told matter of factly; we don't sell smoked salmon anymore.  WHAT? Wait, what?  "we-do-not-sell-smoked-salmon" No more smoked salmon?!  At a New York style cafe/deli?  Blasphemy!

yR_Eyjp58p-bAwORI-B3Jg.review_text: Hey, Mr. Max, what's up with all the mirrored walls in this place.  I mean, I can be as vain as the next person, but there's only so much of myself, I can look at.  Also, while you're at it, Mr. Max, maybe you should train your servers not to have a horrified look of disgust on their face when asked by a patron if a particular item on the menu is good or not.  The server tried to cover it up by saying, "Oh, no, no, it's good, it's really good, I DO like it!"  I mean, I may be a little slow, but I'm not that slow.  It probably would have helped also if the server could have looked me in the eye, at any point, during the time he was providing service to our table.    If the food made up for the lack in service, I would have given a higher rating, but unfortunately, my food was also not up to par.  I had the BBQ pulled pork sandwich, which comes with sweet potato fries and coleslaw.  The meat and BBQ sauce was bland, and the roll didn't really stand up to the sauce, which made the sandwich bread basically turn mushy.  The best part of my meal was the sweet potato fries and even they were just average, really.  They weren't as crunchy or as flavorful as I'd prefer.  Also, at the end of our meal, we were overcharged for one of the items because they had not corrected the price on the lunch menu and charged us the price from their dinner menu instead.  If the person who was overcharged wasn't such a penny pinching, Groupon deal using, tightwad, none of the rest of us would have caught that error. The server apologized and corrected the error, but seemed a little irked by the complaint in general.    With so many other restaurant options in the area, I don't think I'll be coming around to Max's again, anytime soon.

G-BqlQjScP-WHAY2QtNBZQ.review_text: Unfortunately it appears as though there is new ownership at this location, and the patrons, kitchen and wait staff bear the brunt of the corners which are obviously being cut. The quality of the service and the food has gone way down in the past year, which is unfortunate because I used to adore Max's!   I've loved going to Max's for over 15 years, both in SF and the former Walnut Creek location. I work directly across the street from the Van Ness location so I've frequented their deli counter quite often for lunch over the past 3 years. Unfortunately, however, the past couple of times that I've ordered in, seated at a table,  the wait staff has been overwhelmed, the orders were mixed up, and the food was not very good quality. For example:  May 2009 - I had dinner before the symphony with a group of about 5-6 people. I understand the restaurant was busy because of the groups of people going to the theater, but isn't that the reason for the location? Max's Opera cafe, next to the Opera house? Unfortunately, however, on a Saturday night they were way understaffed so the experience turned out to be downright painful.  I had ordered the Caesar salad with salmon, a $15.99 dish, not chump change for a salad. It came to the table after I had to wait while all of the other dishes were served, and it did not have any salmon. Or Parmesan cheese, or even dressing. It was a bowl of bare lettuce! The server somehow didn't even notice this (or maybe they were hoping I wouldn't). So when I brought this to the server's attention they responded with, "Oh, yeah, we're pretty busy. I'll see what I can do". After 15 minutes of waiting for them to come back, while everyone else around the table were finishing their meal, another server brought me a tiny little condiment dish of dressing to go with my bare lettuce. And still no salmon. Long story short, I clearly did  not get what I ordered, I was unable to finish my meal because it took so long to straighten it out, and the server didn't apologize or offer to take it off the bill! I couldn't even talk to the manager because apparently they were too busy calming down other irate customers. I was so shocked at how atrocious the experience was that I chose not to return for the better part of this past year.  But since time heals all wounds, and who knows if that was just a particularly off day, I decided to try it out one more time and give them a chance. So, just yesterday, I made one more effort to have lunch before going to see Wicked at the Orpheum with my sister. When we were seated, I had asked to start our meal with their famous cheesy garlic bread appetizer that I've adored since I was in high school. The server didn't know what I was talking about, and apparently they don't serve it anymore. This news broke my heart, it was an institution of Max's for as long as I can remember! If anyone is reading this review that works there, please push to bring it back!  So, instead of the bread, I asked for the Portabello mushroom appetizer, and specifically said we'd like it before our meal. Then my sister ordered a burger and I ordered a soup and salad.   And a few minutes later, a new server delivered our food, but apparently they had forgotten to put the mushrooms in the system and our main dishes were brought out but there was no appetizer. And my Caesar salad didn't have the anchovies I ordered or the right dressing and the croutons were very hard and stale (I guess I just can't win with that dish!). So since by this point we had a new server (the original one was MIA), I went ahead and asked them to cancel the appetizer since we already got our meals and the kitchen hadn't started making the mushrooms so no harm no foul. But lo and behold, ten minutes later a THIRD server brought us the appetizer half way through our meal, even though I asked for it to be canceled. And we couldn't find our original server, and they charged us for the mushrooms even though we barely touched them through our meal.  All I can say is that I don't know what's going on with this location, maybe it's the stressed economy, but I'm not returning until I know that their service and management has improved significantly and the patrons can expect consistent quality. What an unfortunate turn of events to find out one of our favorite restaurants has gone so down hill. :(

TdwK9CyzBKRmEs_WJW0Ppw.review_text: "Such a nice little Jewish deli" my grandmother would say. Get your matzo balls and pastrami here. The food's gone a little downhill lately, but still big, satisfying portions with a hell of a lot of hutzpah (sp?).

x-8MamivBk3ZXMPUca1fMw.review_text: Myself and my mom had a cup of matzah ball soup and split a reuben sandwich with corn beef. The reuben itself wasn't that impressive, but tasty enough. On the other hand, the matzah ball soup was delightful. But just  a warning- the portions are HUGE. SLLYr_2pqQkHj8jHQUkZWQ.review_text: GREAT FUN FOR KIDS AND GROWN UP KIDS  I forgot about this place until I was thinking of a fun place to have dinner with kids. I have such fond memories of eating here and basically gorging myself on too much of everything. The wait staff take turns singing at the mic hamming it up, which is kind of the shtick of Max's "Opera" Cafe. SC5gAEQZD1HNGY8csv9k6g.review_text: This place is okay. The setting is really nice and does have that historical feel. The food and the portions are good-sized. There is a LOT to pick from. 275LU0YLfAQPNsamNql4mA.review_text: After calling in to make sure they had the Fantasy Torte in stock, we headed to Max's from our dinner location.  There used to be a Max's down here in San Jose where I could get my fix of the Fantasy Torte, but that is no longer the case, so I was thrilled to find out I could have a piece last night.  We arrived at the Van Ness location about 9:00.  There was only a scattering of tables with customers finishing up their meals, but it took over five minutes before a server acknowledged that we sat down.  After giving us eye contact, the server again disappeared for a few minutes before coming over to greet us.  All of that waiting time was dangerous, because I actually looked at the dessert menu.  It was a done deal that I would have the fantasy torte, but the B52 sundae was calling out to me as well.  The wheels in my brain were turning, so I asked the server to check if they had a whole Fantasy Torte in the kitchen somewhere.  They did, so I knew exactly what to order.  I had the simplistic B52 sundae, which was just vanilla ice cream, whip cream, and a shot of Kahlua, amaretto, and Bailey's. In addition, I bought a whole fantasy torte to take home.  We cut off one slice to devour the perfect combination of cheesecake, chocolate mousse, and chocolate cake covered in chocolate.  AHHH!  We also ordered a piece of New York cheesecake with blueberries and some drinks.  Service left a lot to be desired, but Max's was able to fill my craving for the Fantasy Torte.  I sliced, wrapped, and froze the rest at home.  Now I won't have to drive to San Francisco the next time I want to dive into my favorite rich, creamy, decadent dessert.  Thanks Max!

G7tO_4epV6bdx70zqQWYag.review_text: Came here with a group of people and made reservations ahead of time. The service was very inattentive and rude. Possibly it was because we are young people. 8jwj4b-3_ksh4ZQSShOjiA.review_text: This place is a shell of its former self.  We ate here on Monday evening May 4th after finishing an event at the nearby War Memorial Opera House.  It was raining and we didn't feel like going far.  It's been awhile since we ate here and remembered that the food was good.  Boy were we disappointed. T5T_SAuW2uFuiJNQ--mtKg.review_text: This updated review is a few months past due, as it should have been done on September 25, 2013.  First of all, there aren't too many restaurants that have excellent food and ambiance in the Civic Center area and/or close by the SF State Building.  Maestro's is long gone and I do miss their chicken crepes.  The choices of restaurants are limited.  O3 Bistro changed up their menu...nice ambiance but the luncheon menu selection ain't what it used to be.  After 40+ years of working for the state government, it was time for me to start a second journey (heading out the door and toward retirement).  My colleagues gave me a farewell luncheon on September 24 at Max's Opera Cafe, and they were kind enough to do so.  I didn't have the heart to tell two of my colleagues (organizers of the luncheon) that I was not (and still not) a big fan of Max's.  The menu selections were okay; and all I could hope for was improvement in customer service.    Last year I attended a farewell luncheon, and the service was slow, especially for people who ordered the Asian chicken wrap.  Most of us had already eaten over half of our lunch when the waitstaff brought out the wrap.  They claimed they were not fully staffed that day.  Even my Arnie Palmer was sour.    The customer service improved and the waitstaff was more attentive and accommodating.  My turkey sandwich was okay.  At least there was more gravy on the mashed potatoes.  My Arnie Palmer tasted better.  Overall rating:  no more and/or less than a 3.25.

PUpe8mov9lF8mZzJWwxPng.review_text: Come here for the portions, not for the nuanced flavor! It reminds me of the interior of a Sambo's restaurant from the early 70s. The food is decent, never awful, and the serving sizes are GENEROUS. They also have a full bar which helps on those evenings when you have to wait for a table.

LvO583AanpVEcP2GLplUxw.review_text:
I was walking around town with my girlfriend and a friend last night desperately looking for somewhere to eat. It was getting later and things were closing. Then I remembered hearing about this Max's place not too far from where we were. I am from the East Coast and have had my fill at the NJ/NY/Philly delis and have never been disappointed. I was curious to see if this place could satisfy as well.
  ABSOLUTELY TERRIBLE!
  The server was perhaps the worst I have ever had. She didn't listen to a word any of us said. My girlfriend asked for a lemon slice for her water three times and the waitress still didn't bring it after 20 minutes, so I went to the the back and found her and kindly asked her for it. She apologized but kept up her goofy grin. Then we ordered and got our food. I ordered the brisket, which was dry and bland, joined by practically raw broccoli and a latke that was basically IHOP hashbrowns in circular form.   So moral is, the food was mediocre at best and definitely not worth the price and the service was downright terrible. I would never go to this place again and would not recommend it to anyone.

3u1MMvQtFenqQNiMmj0w3w.review_text: Food 5 stars, service 1 star, 3 stars is generous  We came here for a late lunch and it was very crowded. dwFYOIgv6QEk51xu2KdH-A.review_text: Another old friend in the feed-my-face business. Before there was a chain, there was Max's Opera Cafe. 0ub8BLvHuXcKNSXay5zaQg.review_text: Very reliable.  Big servings of good food at a good price. Great place to dine - lunch or dinner - with visiting family. Very good service. Open late.

8Nvvqnb60aFlZutylZd-Aw.review_text: Been to this place a million times.  Yummy food.  Better than Hard Rock Cafe.  Great deserts.  I really enjoy the atmosphere.

uuCeUbhgT98f1OtR69ck6A.review_text: Great place for lunch or pre-SFS dinner. Good food, good service, and not too loud!

AA4EmkZwGfgpezbJH90WDw.review_text: The warning is etched on the door. This is a bad place for a diet! No kidding! We went in anyway and decided to let it all hang out being New Year eve! We were hopeful that we can get a good meal and be entertained by their talented servers, as after all, we haven't been into Max's for well over 15 years. But alas! I now remember why we stayed away. Their glory days seemed over as we ended up getting neither.  The evening started pleasantly enough with live piano playing in the background. The dining room was nicely decorated for the holiday season and appeared cozy and swanky. The Christmas lights stylishly lit up the bar area and the glass windows.  Even with a full house, the muted conversation and soft piano music added some class and sophistication to the ambiance. Being a fan of the opera, I was somewhat disappointed that none of the servers sing anymore. This used to be a unique draw for Max's during their heyday.   The server could have been a little more attentive but overall pleasant and friendly. Soups, salads, burgers, sandwiches, pastas, desserts etc. ...You name it; Max's have them all!  One can say Max's is like a glorified diner. We shared a hearty bowl of Russian Cabbage Soup ($8.00) sans beets. I assume this was the non-beets version of borscht. It was instead tomato-y and the other ingredients were cabbage with chock-full of beef giving the soup a savory, beefy flavor. With a subtle sweet and sour taste, the soup was great though not over-the-top great. (4 stars)  In the mood to play "Finding a needle in a haystack"? Try Max's Famous Crab Cakes ($17.00). Two good-sized crab cakes were served but where was the crabmeat? Bland! Bland! Bland! They looked like frozen patties with tartar sauce on top, which by the way was good but cannot save the underwhelming crab cakes. The saving grace for this dish was the red cabbage and jicama slaw that came with a mustard caper aioli. (2 stars). Skip!  Tri-Mushroom Fettuccine ($17.00) wasn't bad but needed help.  Even without any culinary background, I still know it was time to add Parmesan for better flavor; to spice the pasta with a little chili crushed peppers and to add a cautious touch of salt. I am not a huge fan of rosemary and thyme bunches and had to toss them. I wish Max's were more generous with the tri-mushrooms (portabella, shitake and button). The mushrooms were delicious though, and were sautéed with fresh herbs, evoo and toasted garlic. The fettuccine was a toothsome morsel, had a good bite or al dente. (3 stars)  We thought we needed to order at least one sandwich since Max's is known for their deli meats. Since no one cared for a Reuben or Corned Beef, we settled on a Patty Melt ($15.00) that came highly recommended from a young friend who had no qualms with fat and cholesterol! I bit my tongue and reluctantly agreed.  Why not... today was NYE? We ordered the works and it came loaded with cheese, caramelized onions and 1000 Island on grilled rye. It was sinfully rich alright and sinfully tasty as well while you chomp into the cheese, the onions, the medium rare meat and only to sober up with the down-to-earth taste of rye. Yay! There was no guilt feeling at least today...it only starts the next day or the New Year! (4 stars)  The tart and aromatic Key Lime pie ($8.00) was just the way I remembered it from 15 years ago and provided a happy ending.... for the year 2014, I mean. The sweet and flaky crust was filled with a creamy smooth lime flavored filling and topped with a dollop of whipped cream. It was very refreshing to your palate. (4 stars)

1zqSfVdtFZYgEeV5s-FPyw.review_text: Their Matzo Ball Soup is the only game in town. Drinks are generous. If you're in the neighborhood, stop by. Watch out though - the waiters sing at the piano.
