5izbs0G2wOwnMfRiAcG_1g.review_text: Just around the corner from the Symphony is a New York-style deli where the pastrami comes in the fistful and the cheesecake could serve as ballast on a windy day.  To add to the throwback charm, the waiters are well-dressed and a musician tends a piano in the corner.   To say the place has charm undersells it's greatest feature.  Sure, you can go anywhere in the area for a nice dinner before the show.  But a night at the symphony is all about doing something classic and vintage, and I can't think of a better pairing.

R-QjIrJX8b0MuPZIuL4lTQ.review_text: I took an important client to dinner, and things started out shaky when the server could not answer simple questions about our drink options. The food was mixed; delicious chop with inedible mashed potatoes, for example. The issue of incompetence came when paying the bill. The server returned to the table and announced loudly, "your credit card was declined". Not only was this without class and courtesy, it was embarrassing to my company in front of my client...as well as in front of the tables around us who obviously heard him. The same thing happened with the second and THIRD credit cards, and the server was even more rude saying, "your cards are no good," with a manner clearly expressing frustration with ME. I phoned the card issuer from the table and was told that no charges had been attempted. After asking to see the terminal printout, I saw it clearly stated "modem error, unable to connect". The server, or cashier, or whoever...was incompetent, and the server was not trained in proper etiquette for handling such situations -- making the customer and his guest feel embarrassed, insulted, and mistreated. I will not return.

KFAHRfMI41SWzCm-MwWU_Q.review_text: Van Ness Street with all the Opera, Symphony and Ballet Crowd. I don't love the drafty areas but it adds a bit of authenticity to the idea of a deli in New York. The singers range from bad to horrible, it's wonderfully tacky. It's a fun place to come for a huge dessert while out partying it up in the big city. But what I don't understand is why they didn't hire Amanda Lamb, one of the best singers. Or me, for example.

UXbCcmkYGl3DH_Py5UOtbQ.review_text: Max's and I go way back.  Back to the original diner on 3rd, which was marvelous, a real diner w/ good diner food.  We've eaten at Max's in Corte Madera, the late and unlamented Max's Opera Cafe in Walnut Creek, whose singing wait staff were probably part of the farm team for this one, the excellent but short lived one across from the ballpark and the execrable one in San Ramon.  We've had good meals at this one, but this wasn't one and I doubt we'll bother w/ Max's again.  Dennis Berkowitz is famous for his dislike of critics and still has a handwritten diatribe against one of Michael Bauer's reviews framed on the wall.  When Max's food was good that was cute.  As the quality of the food has deteriorated over the years it's lost its charm.    We were told there would be a 45 minute wait and it was about that.  I ordered a lemon drop.  The best thing about it was the service (Alan brought it).  If the lemon drop at 2nd Street Bistro in Williamsburg was a 5, this was a 1.  It was thin, pale and tart.  The only sweetness was provided by the sugar on the rim.  Not a particularly appealing drink.  When we were seated our waitress immediately started to try to upsell us.  We told her we weren't interested in another drink and she pushed more than I thought was OK.  We told her we had an 8:00 concert.  By this time it was 7:00.  She brought us a basket of lovely warm rolls and butter.  Two of the rolls had raisins in them and one was plain sourdough.  They were tasty.  She took our order.  I had been debating between the mojito skirt steak, marinated in mint and lime and the traditional brisket.  Alan decided on the skirt steak, so I ordered the brisket.  Bad move.  We told the waitress we wanted to split a chopped vegetable salad.  The salad arrived unsplit, no extra plate.  Shortly after, she brought the entrees.  Alan's was cooked medium rare, as ordered.  It was good.  He gave me plenty bites.  The brisket, not so good.  It was sliced thin and wasn't especially moist or tasty.  Tam's is better, Bo's is better, mine is better, almost everyone's is better.  The best part was the roasted carrots that came w/ it.  I gave Alan lots of bites.  Of the brisket, not the carrots.  I got the better deal.  Our waitress was scarcely in attendance.  She checked by twice, Alan requested more water and the second time she brought it.  It didn't help the experience any that the tables were so close together that our "table mates" on one side were a singularly unpleasant pair about our age, of uncertain relationship, who gossiped about others' illnesses and deaths and sniped at each other throughout, bickered over sharing a desert, then figured out to the penny what each owed.

sjXC5pTebfGMZzP-9fpxTw.review_text: A surprisingly good choice for brunch. You'll be surrounded by old folks but they are all definitely harmless. The food is delicious if a tad on the higher side but each dish is MORE than enough for more one person!  Ask for extra free bread if you want.   USEFUL TIP: Buy the gift cards from Costco if you plan on coming back. You'll save 25% off!

R4DVayqiW63jHle7AG_NXQ.review_text: Skip the Cheesecake factory and come here! You won't have to wait nearly as long!  They do have a great cheesecake and some other fantastic desserts... including a fat free rootbeer float, try to go to the cheesecake factory and find that!  But typically, the food here is naturally a diet killer, because they give HUGE portions and just the dishes alone are not good for the weight concious. Shared a huge plate of nachos, the fat free rootbeer float, a cheesecake, a sundae, and one other dessert with some friends.... the sundae was the traditonal one, the chocolate sauce was fizzing right out onto the plate... how do they DO that?  It all was fantastic. I also had a non-alcoholic mojito, which was an AMAZING substitute for the alcoholic one, but it could have been a little sweeter, though.  Things are a little high, but the portion sizes are huge. Service is great, too! Waitstaff is  very, very friendly! You are definitely getting what you pay for. It's always good to go there with friends so you have people to help you with what you order so you won't have to take in all of those calories all by yourself!

WD0pchQWVY5tBbPqRq4zjQ.review_text: I like Max's as much as the next guy.they have a wide variety menu and I always love that. However, it's not fine dining. I got a cold turkey sandwich and a salad and it was good. The service was good and the place was very clean. However it's not a place I don't want to date, and it's a little bit too far from my work. I'd really need a good reason to return to Max's.

ekMCS7A8Cz-Yc0pKOAIZew.review_text: I have been here several times. The food is not really worth the price--$16-$23 for an okay-sized, okay-tasting entree. I kind of want to bump it up a star because we had our first date at the bar here, but this place is a solid 3. However, this is the place to be if you want to hear your waiter sing opera.  Try the blood orange martini! (Also pricey but damn delicious.)

lTSOYYA8RbW1SB7C7y1piA.review_text: Max's is a nice place to go for a casual sit down meal when you're craving traditional american fare.  I've had great service (with one exception; at Max's on the Square once) and I can't imagine a better salad than the skirt steak cobb.  It's amazing.    Too bad Max's on the Square closed.  It was a nice option before going to the theater.

PWohtvH6nTdvGCGeRzoUuQ.review_text: Max's serves mediocre food for high prices.  Come on, $12 for a sandwich?  Salads and entrees are nothing special, sometimes pretty bad.  Considering that you can wait a really long time to get seated, I'm convinced that people only come here because the menu has a wide variety.  That said, you could do worse.

dMm2Py7a-bmV2Q0Qn_Bfug.review_text: I have gone to this restaurant many times over the 30+ years it has been around. It offers comfort food (including deli food) with large portions, and reasonable prices. The quality has slipped on some items (largely due to new recipes, which were not an improvement, the pot roast being one example). Some of the items I like are the bistro salad, the matzot ball soup, the Russian cabbage soup, the latkes, and the sandwiches (esp. corned beef, pastrami, and burgers). Very good service, and comfortable atmosphere.

ZM3Y7pPuKu67Q_FOLqGx7A.review_text: OK, the skinny to sum up quick: Sit at the bar and eat, or you will wait a while.No Reservations. But....The food was good. All I had was the ' Guy's Chinese Chicken Salad" at a half order, and the $#!+ was still big.  And a couple lookers ( lady workers) at that place.I would go again. Perhaps....

tvFO96Y1_T7clh0pnigwTA.review_text: Okay, four stars for food and service because there aren't that many other good options within a reasonably short walking distance of work.  Minus one star because it is so close to work and you can't avoid seeing co-workers and that can be annoying sometimes when you just want to enjoy a juicy pastrami sandwich alone.  They get that star back for the pastrami sandwich though.  And the delicious tuna caper melt and shrimp louie salad.  So why only three stars?  Because for some reason they charge more for food than the Max's in Burlingame and Redwood City.  Add the SF surcharges and that just plain sucks that you have to pay more because you're in the city.

XLBnrtKqheG2lNdHIXc9Aw.review_text: Max's is one of my g/f's favorite places to eat in the city.  It definitely did not disappoint.  I had the meatloaf w/mashed potatoes, gravy and roasted carrots.   Since I was a kid, I haven't been much of a meatloaf eater.  Even more rare, I actually ordered it at a resturaunt.  It didn't disappoint, tho.  If fact I filled up on too much raisin bread rolls and salad, so I just made sure I ate as much of the meatloaf as possible.  1st:  Raisin bread rolls-F*ck Yeah!  2nd: Heart of Romaine Salad-  This is really basic.  Just the heart of a Romaine head with red onions and halfed cherry tomatoes.  I got my salad with the lemon vinagrette.  Really tasty!  3rd:  The meatloaf tasted like an original meatloaf.  This isn't your mom's meatloaf...    Cooked well and still juicy and tender.  Had to eat it all cause you know it wouldn't be the same cold or reheated.  If I wasn't staying in a hotel, I definitely would have taken some home to make a meatloaf sandwich.  The only thing I wasn't thrilled with was the opera singing.  I would like to give props to the Host and the Waiters for performing, even though I didn't really enjoy it.  Aside from the singing (which wasn't bad, I'm just not into it) I thought it was great that the waiters doubled as performers.

kxhXpQexE5W-EaJuZP81rw.review_text: Good food. Service was fast and not intrusive. Very pleased. Would dine here again

CiYRhDyFbsDbWR45uv822w.review_text: I like the location.    I love their lemonade.  A fan of their specialty sandwiches, whether it's the pastrami, grilled three-cheeses or crabcake...drool!   And I love how their specials are always so different, and sometimes seasonal.   It's very American fare, but better than Mel's, and they get points for having the specialty items!  Hey, they try!  You've been warned: Service can be pretty bad, when they slammed!  Otherwise, they are friendly and helpful!  Absolute diner feel.    I have a preference for having lunch there...just like that kind of food for lunch moreso than dinner.  And I always have leftovers.   I actually would not recommend this place for desserts--very disappointing, and too sweet for me.  Just go to Safeway and buy the white sheet cake, m'kay?

MmakTmmG25XqwJPmn4RcIQ.review_text: My wife and I were eating there 8 to 10 times a year. In the last year, or so, the menu has changed and not for the better. Very little fish unless you want a salmon or salad.  Service is slower now with less attention to details. Their side door is open from the street and the last time we were there management had to chase out homeless.

Valva2MGzBW8ux3641YINA.review_text: I've been coming here for years. I haven't been in a long time, got the matzo ball soup, AMAZING! I got the bowl and it wasn't big enough!! I wanted more. The latkes are always good with apple sauce and sour cream. And the chocolate cake is to die for! I am not a huge chocolate cake freak but you really need to get it at Max's, it's the perfect chocolate cake!

N_jbiGiW3oPxTAjiDiA1AQ.review_text: I know Max's is considered by most to be passe and definitely not "cool" but I am still a fan.  The food is generally very good quality, though sometimes they miss the mark.  Portions are definitely oversized, so best to take half home and get two meals for the price of one, rather than complaining about getting overstuffed.  Love their soups and salads are generally good also. If your not worried about taking a couple of years off your life, try the Reuben sandwich, french fries, onion rings, and/or desserts.

CoR4kuL55yL-38WXncSwpA.review_text: my wife & i love the food at max's opera cafe.  the waitstaff is decent & pretty attentive to your needs.  the restaurant is clean, it is laid out pretty well & fairly comfortable.  there is live music & the singing is fairly entertaining.  we typically start our meal off with the bbq pork piezzle.  my wife used to order the firecracker shrimp but since they have taken it off the menu she now orders the penne pasta.  i typically will only order the new york steak rare.  the food is pretty decent at max's & we are never surprised how our food comes out from the kitchen.  by the time we are finished with our dinner we typically will not have room for desert.   if you are a steak or beef lover i recommend getting the new york steak only.  i have tried the angus rib eye steak here & its not to my liking, its tender but pretty fatty which is not a good thing in this case.  the new york steak is just as tender, thick & juicy, with alot of flavor without the high amount of fat.    overall, it's a great restaurant to get some pretty good food.  its convenient to eat there before or after going to the sf opera house, sf symphony or sf ballet as they are all within walking distance.  they open fairly late so post event coffee & desert are a must.  the prices are not too bad & are fairly reasonable.  the street parking is hit or miss but there are plenty of parking lots within walking distance.

OfWGzwXQLFfQCw7s3VRhCQ.review_text: My husband and I went for the 1st time, amazing really good food I was very pleased. Thank you

zXi8WzXV2lfefnnzPEnOOw.review_text: I just jumped over to Max's for my lunch break for some dessert so I cant atttest to the rest of the food. Only the mud pie and the service. Dude was pleasant, moved at a good pace and got me back to work right on time.  The mud pie was purdy f-ing good but I dont recommend eating it on your own unless you are shooting for a diabetic coma, which I am just coming out of as I type this.

mQUoN1QcGI3AEpu5su1PHg.review_text: I'm sad to say that I can only give Max's Opera Cafe two stars right now. We hadn't been to this location for awhile so we were in the neighborhood and thought it would be a good choice.  It was about 10p by the time we walked in and we were surprised to see the place was pretty empty--not a good sign on a Saturday night.  The host didn't acknowledge us because she was too busy talking with her co-workers. Strike one. Once we were seated, we were given menus that were dirty. Strike two. The server was very nice, however, and attentive. We ordered our food and it came out relatively fast but it was disappointing. Strike three.  What it looks like is this location has deteriorated, unfortunately, which is a shame. Hopefully, the Geary Street location is still good because we've always liked Max's.  Right now, I don't see us returning to this location.  Sorry.

q-hh1rBIOGBzROGlz-km4g.review_text: I gave this a thought for a month, and after seeing some negative reviews, I decided to justify myself for this review.  As an entire restaurant, it's 3 stars because I like the way it's set up.  It's gotta a style.  Max's to me is one of the restaurants that represent America.    I don't want to remember this bitter dining experience, so I'm just listing up the lessons I learned from it.  1. Don't push yourself to eat at a restaurant near closing time.  Your waitress wants to go home & so do kitchen people (see the photos).  The bathroom could be nasty.  2. Don't eat at a restaurant when the manager or owner isn't present.  It's just my guess, but things could have been better with him.  3. Don't take out desserts; they might be spoiled, and you get VERY disappointed on the way back home in your car.  I was so upset that made me speechless the entire trip (which my hubby might have appreciated, which I won't know).  4. Following #3, if you ever take out desserts, don't get your expectation too high; always be prepared the unexpected & the worst.  To conclude, it might have been mere bad timing.  Max's could be a REALLY nice restaurant, and I REALLY regret to say this, but I'm resting Max's for good in my book.

WtDdZoi5HDxFUb3vvbk_1w.review_text: interesting place - waitresses are also good singers, and they will sing to some broadway tunes during their shift....food wise - it's okay  I had better. If you are in diet, not the best place to be. They have BIG tasty desserts :)

h9GVLf7Crm4kNuLFBDnEIw.review_text: I came online to give this place a 4 star rating. I thought about it and maybe the service could still be improved. However, the food and service was better than last time - so I'd give it a 3.5 instead of a 3.0 stars.  I had the Thursday lunch box special. For $10.99 I got the turkey sandwich) warm and it came with mash potatoes and a free fountain soda/coffee/or iced tea. I chose the iced tea - actually they gave me warm tea and a glass of ice and I put it in myself- unsweetened style my favorite. They have lunch box specials for everyday of the weekday. I was impressed because the sandwich was pretty good. I also asked for extra gravy and it was just perfect- not too salty and included mushrooms in the mix. I thought the mushrooms could have been more cooked, but other than that the lunch was really good.  I felt a bit cramped in the booth seat I was in, and our table was a bit close to the others.   The service was fine. I think the waitress could have been more attentive to us, but I didn't think she wasn't either. It was somewhere in the middle.

2tpijc4XAkYo2an0UnQrNA.review_text: Well all I had was coffee and a brownie. But the server treated us as if we were special anyway. He was very nice and recommended the brownie over the eclaire which was an excellent choice! The brownie is a pillow of chocolaty goodness,tender and melts in your mouth. The coffee was fresh and strong, full of flavor.  I asked if I could get a tomato and the guy gave me a couple extra! I plan to go back after I saw the amazing looking sandwiches!

cAJzku7JP33TqYXgBt9rDw.review_text: I'm not happy with the health insurance service charge.  For whatever historical reasons, waiters count on tips as part of their income. Part of this is supposed to go towards their health insurance as many restaurants do not provide insurance. Thus, I would think that you deduct the service charge from what you were going to tip anyways. But our party hit the minimum size for automatic tip service charge.  Food was kind of blah... less than I remembered. The chicken pot pie was pretty decent, but other tshings -- such as their matzo ball soup -- not so good. With surcharge, the cost of the meal skyrockets. I will no longer dine at this establishment.

ooButTCX3SpC_rQdG37jgw.review_text: I used to go to Max's ALL the time...I brought friends frequently whenever we had something to celebrate (every night of the week there were long lines until just before closing:not any more) EVERYTHING IN THE PAST WAS GOOD to excellent ..not in recent history Every place goes through changes....however this evening had to be amongst the MOST DISAPPOINTING NON-MEALS OUT I EVER HAD. 2NzZ1q8H5g4Y1U4FqXQ_iQ.review_text: Huge portions and great service are the stars at this Van Ness St. Location.  You won't be disappointed with any of the dishes.  My favorite is the Pastrami on rye which hits the spot.  Soups are also delightful and great on a cold SF foggy night.  Great place to grab a meal before you see the Opera or Symphony.

VUsAJ_M17I8HEqCg34tEJA.review_text: I can honestly say that I've been coming here since I was in grade school. It became one of the many places we would frequently visit as a treat everytime we were in the city, especially after watching a show.  Anyway, the food is not 5-star classy but I must say that I have never had a meal that I didn't like. I've tried their salmon, the Philly cheesesteak sandwich, burgers/sliders, crab cakes, caesar salad, Reuben sandwiches, steaks, and many of their pastas as well. To this day, my favorite is the skirt steak MEDIUM and shrimp scampi. Desserts here are delicious! I ALWAYS get the sundae with multiple scoops of vanilla ice cream with bittersweet hotfudge, marshmallow cream, and candied peanuts.. generous enough to share between 4 people and still feel satisfied! NOMNOM   The portions here are HUGE! Plus they give you fresh and warm bread rolls (sourdough and this dark sweet cinnamony kind too).   The atmosphere is pretty chill. It's kind of like a high-end diner? But not high end like a No-Jeans as T-shirt policy. It's a casual environment and you can see people of all kinds and ages dressed down and up. They have a full- service bar (hard liquor, wine, beer) and a piano/piano-man that plays music to which most of the waiters/waitresses will sing with to entertain you.   Bathrooms are pretty clean which is a major plus as well!  Lastly, this place has a bunch of rules that the restaraunt/waiters/waitresses have to follow. You can find them printed on the napkins and in the menu. They're pretty funny and I'm always hoping they break one so I can get a free drink or free whole cake or something!! ---but nope nothing yet and I've been coming here since I was 6!! YAY FOR MAX's!!

IWbdz__L39NNqJbIXhDU8A.review_text: Dined here prior to Colors of Christmas concert. I ordered a sandwich and the hubby ordered a burger.  I agree with the other reviews about the bread being stale. I dont mind paying $12.00 for sandwiches if the bread is good; the bread used for the burger was practically falling apart! Never coming back to this place.

hf7H-Z0FNjvm7WMgUp_laQ.review_text: I've been going to Max's for over 20 years and it's my neighborhood comfort restaurant. You have to know what to order though, and I'm glad that I do. Big flavorful salads, wraps and tasty burgers. I also like the potato pancakes, sliders and three mushroom fettuccine. One of my favorites was the roasted chicken with a big heap of mashed potatoes, but their entrees are now limited, which is disappointing. Large portions and good service (when they're not busy) and there's a take-out counter. Don't care for their potato salad, but I like their coleslaw. Quality of cocktails can be a bit inconsistent.

Ok5f4AjOAs1mzjBz7NsoqA.review_text: Great location, can't argue that.  And the crowd, is pretty funky, Ballet, Symphony, concert goers, that's fun.  There's a vibe about the place.    It's a little too casual, like a deli.  But without the great deli food.  I'm a walker arounder.  Before I eat somewhere, I'm peering between kissing couples to see what they ordered.  And after all the walking, studying, thorough research, I went with a salad.  What's that telling you?   I snacked a little before coming here, big mistake.  I should have ordered a burger or something straight forward.  The salad blew!  If I read some reviews before going, I should have ordered a phatty dessert.  I agree with the rules, sayings painted up in the restaurant.  Give me some paint, I'll get some shit up there.  But, it was neither funny, witty, or even purposeful.  I wanted to shoot that placard with a shotgun.    And the waitstaff singing opera?  How stoned were you Max designing that concept?  Have a seal and a beachball - that would be fun.

jkr3YVCEoRNKkxinUZpW6A.review_text: There isn't a better place in the city to honor your Jewish roots than at Max's and over a steaming bowl of matzoh ball soup. 8Aq_UdlsrjhBwGWb_U-xRA.review_text: In search of comfort food - that was my goal.  After an afternoon of walking throughout Union Square then walking up into the Tenderloin I made a turn onto Van Ness and ended up at Opera Plaza.  I needed refreshment and I needed nourishment so I decided to step into Max's Opera Cafe.  The only other Max's I've ever eaten in was the one that use to be on Third near the Moscone Center.  I remember I ate there often because their food was always good and "homey".  Max's Opera Cafe was a bit of a disappointment though.  When only the service highlights the visit that's not a very good sign.  I received outstanding service.  I was seated promptly and the waiter/server was polite and courteous throughout the afternoon bringing my beverage to me quickly, bringing my food to me quickly, checking up on me twice and just being a very good waiter.  I ordered the table brewed peach ice tea which I thought was kind of cool and unique.  The waiter brought a tall glass filled to the very top with ice cubes.  He explained to me that the syrupy concoction in the base of my glass was the peach-flavored syrup.  In a small metal pot was a tea bag submerged in hot water.  The waiter suggested that I could mix the tea into the glass whenever I felt like depending on how strong I wanted the tea to be.  I like my tea super strong and the mixed-in ice tea was exactly the refreshment I needed.  I decided against ordering a burger and ended up choosing Max's Famous Meatloaf served with mashed potatoes and a vegetable.  The food arrived in less than five minutes along with a metal basket containing a couple of hot rolls and several cubes of butter.  There was a plain white dinner roll, and a darker roll which had a pleasant cinnamon scent to it.  I cracked open the darker roll to find that it was indeed a raisin roll filled with dark and golden raisins.  The roll had a thin, chewy crust and soft, chewy bread.  It was excellent.  I wish I could have said the same of the main entree.  I'm not sure why the meatloaf is "famous" because it certainly was not for the taste which was pretty generic.  The thick slice of meat patty had good firmness and nice texture, but I was not satisfied with its taste at all.  It was completely covered in a dark brown mushroom sauce which simply tasted sodium heavy.  The potatoes were lukewarm kept on the warm side only because a thick, gooey light brown gravy was piping hot.  The carrots were quite obviously reheated since they had now reached a level of extreme rubberness.  Had there not been diners seated around me I might have certainly tossed a piece of carrot off the table top just to see how high it would bounce.  The desserts looked decadent, but I passed on them.  If there is a next time here I'll consider a burger.  Three stars but just barely.

_BHTC7nyCBoZcfiiD5cOXg.review_text: The first of Max's 17 Laws is testimony to why this dining spot is as popular as it is - "This restaurant is run for the enjoyment and pleasure of our customers, not the convenience of the staff or the owners." Its motto is "Everything You Always Wanted to Eat," while at the same time warning "This is a bad place for a diet!," and no wonder - overstuffed deli sandwiches, gigantic salads, and large-enough-to-share main course specialties, plus addictive fresh-baked breads and decadent desserts made on the premises, have been signature items on the extensive menu from day one. That's not to say that the kitchen doesn't have the diet-conscious in mind. Whether on Atkins or South Beach, those watching their food intake can enjoy a number of items on a carb-conscious menu. Everyone else can indulge in the likes of tender, meaty barbecued spareribs in a tangy sauce, brisket of beef in a honey-caraway gravy, or linguini tossed with portabello mushrooms, roasted garlic, fresh herbs, and extra virgin olive oil. Corned beef and pastrami sandwiches have just the right amount of fat and are as good as any found in New York City. French fries are crisp and relatively grease-free. Even the iced tea is special here - you allow it to brew to the preferred strength in a small pot before pouring it into a tall glass. And when you request a refill, you'll get new tea bags, not just hot water to add to those you've already used. Desserts are sinfully rich and large enough to be enjoyed by two . . . or three. The gimmick that differentiates this Max's from others in the chain are the servers singing operatic arias and Broadway show tunes. Don't be surprised if the waitress who just served your Caesar salad is now in the spotlight belting a la Merman. A word of warning: avoid a table close to the small stage. When the staff isn't singing, a pianist is tinkling the keys, and conversation can be difficult.
